ReviewList.Text: I saw the movie 'Jurassic Park' when I was about ten years old and I liked it, I guess, but I mean, I was TEN, I didn't really understand all the scientific stuff. Just a few months ago, I read the book and I absolutely  LOVED it! At first, I was wary about reading it, it had a lot of techno  science talk in it which I thought I wouldn't understand, but I did get the  basic idea and I thought the book was fantastic!  It is suspensful and  really enjoyable. I recommended it to my friends, but they were like  "Why would you want to read THAT?" (I'm a thirteen-year-old girl  and they were like...whatEVER!) But I really really liked it. I love the  movie too, but the book is more thrilling, if you ask me. I don't see how  anyone could not like the movie though and refuse to read the book  afterward. The movie was excellent too.

Sometimes, in reading science fiction books, readers get lost in the scientific mumbo-jumbo of it all.  Other times, the story is the predominant feature and the scientific parts of the book are overlooked.  Jurassic Park is one of the rare books that pleases both perspectives.  While some of the ideas are far-fetched (what sci-fi book doesn't have those?), the story makes it all believable and entertaining at the same time.  The book was so well-written that it puts the movie version to shame!  Even Steven Spielberg (in my opinion) could not capture all the book had to offer.  This is a quick read that could be completed in a weekend or over a few nights.  This made me a Michael Crichton fan!

It's been a few years since I've read this book, but it still stands out to me as one of my favorite works of (modern) fiction.  This book is very fast paced and when I read it, I had a really hard time putting it down.  I  read it cover to cover almost non-stop.  I can imagine this book becoming a  little more popular again with all the talk of cloning going on and while  the ideas in this book are far-fetched, I'm sure it will help some people  make opinions on whether or not cloning is good or bad.  So, if you're  looking for a great, faced paced sci-fi thriller, you may want to pick up  Jurassic Park.  I also feel the book is much better than the movie despite  the fact that Spielberg directed JP in 1991.  The story line is MUCH more  devolped and the ending is entirely different!  So, if you've seen the  movie and liked it and have yet to read the book, I suggest you do - you  will definitely enjoy this book.

First off, I absolutely love this story - without a doubt it gets 5 stars. Which is what makes the embarrassing number of typos in this edition even more ridiculous. It makes you realize that absolutely no one at the publisher's reads the books after they are printed. It's not like they made a couple simple mistakes, and put "its" instead of "it's" - the typos are literally everywhere, and often not even close to what should've been printed. This is an insult to a classic work by a great author - don't buy it.

Behind all the technothrills in many of Crichton's books and screenplays lies a message: once you start playing God, where do you stop?  In "Jurassic Park", one of Crichton's better novels, there is a basic formula: Dinosaurs + Murphy's Law = Trouble.  Our hero, Alan Grant, a paleontologist with a healthy respect for dinosaurs, and his assistant Ellie Sattler, a paleobotanist, have dug up some interesting dinosaur fossils in the Montana badlands.  Into their camp comes an invitation from a millionaire entrepreneur named John Hammond with a proposal much more interesting: a visit to his unfinished theme park on an island off the coast of Costa Rica.  Off they go in Hammond's private plane, with a lawyer named Donald Gennaro and a slightly wacko mathematician named Ian Malcolm who specializes in chaos theory.  What they find on the island blows their minds into the stratosphere: Hammond's scientists have successfully managed to clone and breed living dinosaurs.  Wowie-kazowie, what a terrific idea for a theme park!  Or so say Hammond and Gennaro, thinking of the astronomical bottom line, but Grant, Sattler, and especially Malcolm, have their doubts: living creatures are unpredictable, you can't know what they will do or how they will react, and if something starts to go wrong in a small way, the subsequent chain of events will guarantee a screw-up in a big way.  Chaos theory rules after all.  ... And when the raptors prove to be almost as smart, and much stronger and faster, than humans, Murphy's Law starts to take over with a vengeance.  ...There's a lesson to be learned in all of this and Crichton grabs us and propels us along in a dizzying ride through almost 400 pages, but the moral is clear: Just because you can try to play God, doesn't necessarily mean it's a great idea.  Nature had a reason to make the dinosaurs extinct, and Mother Nature doesn't appreciate mere mortals messing in her business.  Crichton's characters suffer from his usual lack of development, they're two-dimensional and never really leap off the page, which is the only thing that keeps me from giving this book five stars; because the story, and the dinosaurs, are so fascinating that Crichton could have written another 400 pages and held me mesmerized to the end.  Whatever Crichton's deficiencies as a writer, he is one helluva story teller.

This must be Michael Crichton's best book yet. It has a powerful feeling left inside me because of the fact that something of this caliber could happen. He uses real science together with imagination creating a dream world of dinosaurs. His description is amazing you feel as if you are right next to them feeling their pain and horror. I have to be fair though he showed detail but the fact that he shows every computer screen and the DNA codes made the book a little cluttered. I personally liked the character Ian Malcolm because he reminds me of myself in that he's stuck up about the fact that he knew that they would escape. This book is set apart fro mall others because what if the raptors had gotten onto the mainland? They could have killed a lot of people and that one day something like that might just happen because of the growing interest in genetics and DNA. It even leaves you guessing at the end (did it really work?). It's an amazing plotline that someone would think of an amusement park with something that dangerous and trying to do something so impossible for money is amazing but people might do that. Michael Crichton has written the best books I have read in my entire life. Michael Crichton I salute you. I give Jurassic park 2 thumbs up the best book I have read in a long time.

I thought the book was rather good. The plot and the theory of the DNA in amber was something that never would have crossed my mind. Although I'm not exactly a type of person who is crazy about dinosaurs or even science at  all but the novel makes you think about it and can actually push you toward  getting interested which is a good quality in books in some cases. It was  intelligent and it kept me turning the pages until I was done. The way the  author wrote it was easy for me to follow. The plot was good and  suspenceful and the book fit me very well since I'm a  thriller/mystery/suspence type of person. Although I'm thirteen when I read  and finished it (I read a whole lot of books that are out of my seventh  grade reading level sometimes) I think it's good for young kids who can  really READ but still in the range of older readers. I thought the movie  was good but not exactly sticking too much detail from the book. I would  recommend this book to those who like a good page turner for science and  dinosaurs. :-)

I've seen the movies, but had never bothered to read the book that started it all. Better late than never I suppose. This was by far a much better story than what was conveyed in the first feature film. I had no idea that many of he principal characters differed so tremendously from how they were portrayed in the film. On the big screen, Hammond is portrayed as an eccentric, naive, filthy-rich, and daudling old man. In Crichton's book, he is still a filthy-rich old man, however, he is cold, ruthless, arrogant and calculating. The tyranosaur attack, and the subsequent chase of Grant and the kids, was much more frightening and exciting in the original text. As enjoyable as the movies were, it's a shame they deviated so far from the book. If you're a fan of the motion picture iterations, you will not be able to put this book down.

In this novel, scientists use cloning, PCR techniques, and amphibian development to isolate dinosaur DNA from insects trapped in amber and to grow living dinosaurs for the ultimate in amusement parks. To garner  support for the park, the developer has asked a number of scientists to  visit and to evaluate the facilities and animals. One of these individuals  is a mathematician whose field of expertice is chaos and catastrophe  theory. Thus, the readers learns a little about molecular biology,  paleontology, paleobotany, and an exciting new area of mathematics (a  common characteristic of Dr. Crichton's novels that I find enjoyable is the  education one receives over a wide area of topics). However, things go  wrong and the reader is soon caught up in the adventure. But, I should  point out that both the book and the 1994 film make some serious scientific  errors, particularly in biochemistry and molecular biology. (For example,  Dr. Crichton has his characters insert a genetic "flaw" into the  DNA of the dinosaurs so that, if a dinosaur would escape, it could not  survive in the "wild." The dinosaurs are made to be incapable of  biosynthesizing the amino acid lysine. However, humans [and other mammals]  also can't synthesize lysine! Lysine is one of the nutritionally essential  amino acids [just ask any body builder who often supplement their diets  with lysine tablets]. Nevertheless, humans are able to survive without this  metabolic pathway!) But note that, even with thses flaws, I still gave the  book five stars. These errors (and the "nonerrors") get readers  to thinking about these exciting new fields of human endeavor. And, they  start searching for the answers themselves. I see students doing this all  the time. Crichton should be applauded. The book and the film also  demonstrate the problems with uncontrolled genetic engineering.

Excellent detail and descriptiveness. It is perfect for anyone who enjoys complexities and suspense, but can't stand boring parts. I remember when I first started reading it, I didn't think would like it too much. I read two more pages and after that, read 'till midnight, I swear. One of the things that keeps the book going is the continuous happening of events. Things never stopped popping up after that first part. Another thing was the accuracy on the dinosaurs. He describes every last detail right on the dot to last vertabrae on a tyrannosaur's tail, and I'm serious about that, 37 vertabrae, he says it. I'd give this book a 1,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000-star rating if I could, but they only let me put in five.

I was getting bored one day, so my mother handed me a book. I sat down and started reading this book. It had suspence, drama, and science all jumbled up into one incredible novel of dinosaurs being recreated from a dead  mosquito. And I am glad to say this book was the absolute best I have ever  read in the extent of my memory. This wonderful book was called  "Jurassic Park". It has a wonderful story line and a colorful  cast of characters. I stayed up way passed my designated time to read it,  and no one cared! The best part of it is, it is soooo much better than the  film. Now that I've told you this, I suggest you go out and purchase this  paperback and read 'till you eyeballs fall out!  ~An

Yes, I'm ashamed, because I made the single most common, simple, consumer flaw. I saw the movie, and then I read the book. Obviously, the first contradiction I noticed was that of John Hammond. I expected a sweet old  man with a beard and two grandkids, a Santa Clause who promised the child  his own T-Rex for a pet. Then I had the honor of meeting Crichton's  Hammond, a much more realistic obsessive who was just as brilliant as he  was cold. While I did enjoy the movie and Hollywood's perspective of the  book, I far more enjoyed the book without the Hollywood corruption or  endings. One of the biggest strength's of the book is Crichton's ability to  not only convey the situation, but to include every small detail. The time  he takes in researching his subject pays off greatly, probably the number  one reason he's moved up the #2 slot on my top five picks for reading (a  personal hobby). Right down to how they repair the broken fences, the book  took a risk in attempting to cover every possible field involved, and it  paid off greatly.

I really enjoyed this novel. The writing style of Michael Crichton is absolutely incredible, he has a way were when you are reading you get hooked and never want to put the book down. If you are a fan of the film like I am you will definitely realize from the beginning of this novel that there are some major differences, but I enjoyed that because I have seen the movie many times so I enjoyed that I was able to have new experiences with the novel version of the story.

I read this book when I was in high school which was about 6 years ago and at the time I was quite enthralled with it. I read it again not to long ago and I found it to be just as entertaining as I remembered. I read quite a  few months before the movie came out and I was blown away by that as well.  I find it hard to believe you dont know the story yet but if not check it  out already!

This is one of Crichton's better works in my opinion. I purchased it through the Kindle store to read on my Samsung Galaxy Note. I found the included page numbers to be quite nice after only having percentages before. The story has somewhat of a slow buildup because of the technical aspects presented, but I enjoyed those because I am very science oriented. I enjoyed the book much better than the movie, although both were highly entertaining.
Read it for third time after 20 years. Just as exciting. Interested to see if the new movie is a reboot or continuation
Crichton's greatest novel in my opinion, thoroughly enjoyed it on kindle app! Great for on-the-go reading. Very convenient, love it!
WAY better than the movie. Very easy to understand and action packed.definitley the best book i ever read.the DNA is confsing but if you look and focus on it it makes sence.
It's a great book. I would recommend it to anyone who liked the movies, or is at all interested in dinosaurs.
Fell in love with this book as a child, was tickled pink when it FINALLY came out on kindle. Perfect for adults who knew every dinosaur name as a six year old but can't name over 4 today.

This is the first book I read by Michael Crichton which back in high school and I must say it is still a favorite and I think his best.  If you saw the movie but didn't read the book then you must read it.  Although fair warning they are not the same.  In fact this for me is one of those times when the book is better then the movie.

This book was so detailed... once I started reading it I couldn't put it down! I'm sure you'll say the same thing when you see the book. Michael Crichton has the way to put readers on the edge of their seat, just as the movies did! This book has thousands of cool scenes, tight scenes, and nasty scenes, but hey.... it's still good!

I live in Co Springs where many dinosaur bones have been found.  I have always found the skeletal remains exciting!  The first time I saw the book "Jurassic Park", my best friend in High School was reading it.  I asked her what it was about and she just said "Oh God Holly, I can't and will not put it down!"  I was intrigued. After college I had read most of Michael Crichton's books but had still not read "Jurassic Park".  Then BOOM...the movie is released.  I loved the movie.  I decided to buy the book and see if it was just as thrilling.  "Thrilling" hardly seems fit to describe the book! (my paperback has nail indentations on it!) As I have reviewed before...M.C. loads the first few chapters with some basic, easy to comprehend scientific knowledge...Making it easier to understand the essence of what's going on...even the morality...which is barely discussed in the movie.  I'm talking about the idea of harvesting blood from mosquitos preserved in amber for millions of years.  Mosquitos that John Hammond, (the somewhat delusional "father" of the Dino-theme park idea) harvests to extract Dino-DNA.  ( He believes many of these mosquitos liked to feed from dinosaurs...Could they really do that? Someone tell me.  Dino skin must be inches thick, but anyway,)  He processes the DNA, filling in some missing links, and hatches the little creepies on Isla Nublar, a very secluded and resticted island.  So there it begins. Talk of Dino-DNA is nothing more than a simple cartoon to watch in the movie ( probably for a younger audience to understand), but is discussed in depth in the book.  The main characters are loving, delightful and sometimes downright sarcastic and keep you laughing.  But don't be fooled.  John Hammond has a dream to open a theme park, "Jurassic Park" to the world.  A Place where dinos exsist in confined habitats, guarded by electric fences.  He and the main characters on the island enjoy themselves submerged in a multi-millionare-old enviroment, but I ask you...what happens when the elctricity accidentally shuts down......

Well, I know that little guidelines page tells me I must resist the compelling urge to not write about what others say on this fine book...well what can I say? I'm weak. Too weak to resist the pulling force to my keyboard, and typing a review to try and correct all the misleading comments on this fine piece of literature.  I liked the book, in fact I loved it. It is truly one of the finest and one of Michael's finest books ever written. I can't be the great author he is and type in his defence, but I'll try.  Micheal is a fine writer who has written a fine book, it informs and entertains me, which few novels do. It is true, some of the fact that I am taught is false. Raptors may be quite a bit taller than the book explains them as. Well, I know Michael twisted fact into fiction a bit in the book, but if these facts are so important as many dinosaur super genius' seem to think, well, why write the story at all, why write any story. Fiction IS a distortion of the facts, I mean, if perfect fact is what you strain yourselves to see (or read) then find a nice cozy atlas to curl up by the fire with. Everyone knows that it is impossable to clone dinosaurs with todays technology, the DNA breaks up overtime. But, that is why the book has been placed in the fiction section, IT'S NOT REAL. If fact is issue number one, then all fiction books are too far fetched for you. But action, adventure, and some education on the side is what I found in Jurrasic Park. Of course I know it's not 100% pure unprocessed fact, but that just makes it more fun to read. I doubt the book would be nearly as fun to read if it was more factual about the Raptor size. I can't see everyone running terrified from a pack of 1/2 foot dinosaurs, it's not as scary to most readers, and Crichton knows that, that's why he jacked up their height. The velociraptor was the closes thing he could find to a 6 foot carnisaur. And at that time the "REAL" 6 foot Raptor hadn't yet been discovered. So Michael made the changes for you, the readers, to heighten the reading experiance for us. So, remember that if you are a factual perfectionist if you read this book, and if the twists bug you that much, go to the non fiction section next time. I'm sure they keep accurate records on the proper mating ritual of the duck billed plautipus. If your not that type, prepare yourself for a action packed, on the edge of your seat, and interesting read.  (and I know I probibly spelt 'plautipus' wrong so don't all you perfectionists sue me for bad spelling)  Thank you.  B.A.F

Like many who are familiar with Michael Chrichton, as soon as I found out they were making 'Jurassic Park' into a movie, my initial thought was: "GREAT!...but ONLY if they follow the book." Well they did an okay job (the effects were 1st rate, though) and yes, the story differed in MANY ways from the novel.  I encourage anyone who enjoyed the movie to pick up this fast-paced story of genetic manipulation today.  I DO have to admit they cast Jeff Goldblum PERFECTLY.  He fit Ian Malcom to a TEE. He is one of my favorite fictional characters, and when you read the story you'll know why.  One great annoyance I had with the movies was how a scene from the original 'Jurassic Park' book found its way into 'The Lost World' movie (the opening scene for instance, and the T-Rex thrusting its head through the waterfall...) and the ending of 'The Lost World' was SO different from the book as to make me wonder if they were going to release a novelized version of the movie since it was almost 100% different than the book.  Dennis Nedry was another great casting job (remember Newman from Seinfeld...?) and, well forget the differences, this story deserves to be read, mostly because it is timely and incredibly entertaining.  When was the last time you heard someone say the movie version of a book was better? In this case, the movie cannot even hold a candle to Chrichton's amazing story of bringing the dead back to life by use of genetic science.  He almost makes you believe it could happen...The action never let's up, and the twists and turns and let's not forget the ending being totally different from the movie...it's just a GREAT BOOK.  Get it!  Read it!  Enjoy it!

This book is so cool you think you are really seeing dinosaurs as if they are really alive today. If you liked the movie you will love the book he really goes into detail. The only flaw is it is pretty long but other than  that it is really cool.

Even though this book opens somewhat disjointedly, with scenes from all over the place with characters who serve no purpose but to build suspense before making a quick exit, it delivers what most books and movies fail to do even with a highly plausible premise: a believable scenario in which dinosaurs once again walk the earth.  Crichton's skill is not necessarily in his prose (although I do credit him with inventing the single-sentence paragraph-a tool most suspense authors use today), but in his ability to erect scientific monuments of stone with ideas of straw.  The accusations that his characters are flat are baseless.  Simply because he doesn't droll on ad nauseum about every mundane facet of his characters' backstory or emotive sentiments does not mean they are not lively or relatable, and who can't relate to someone whose in the grip of pulse pounding terror?  The real characters here are the vicious antediluvian beasts, and he brings them to life with unmatched skill.  The dinosaurs people saw in the movie Jurassic Park were the direct product of Michael Crichton's mind, and their personalities are on dramatic display everywhere.  In the end, Crichton was a creative genius, taking thoroughly researched science and marrying it to fantastical imagination, adding a dose of wit and wisdom, he left us with stories to share and enjoy and learn from (both scientifically and morally) for generations to come, and Jurassic Park was his magnum opus: the testimony to everything that he did best.  May he rest in peace.

I was initially impressed by the chaotic beginning featuring the casualty of a raptor attack, a fact which was not revealed but heavily implied. However as the novel began to degrade into a mix of scientific and technological data I was slowly being annoyed, but Crichton was able to mix enough of the techno babble with other scenes to get the reader through to the collapse of the park. This book would have received a 4 star rating from me until page 145 when the Rex chapter kicks in. At this point this novel is no longer a somewhat irritating philosophical debate demonstrates chaos theory which Malcolm, a highly intelligent and somewhat irritating mathematician, has been trying to get across to the characters and the reader up to this point. By this point in the novel it became impossible to put down as I went on a whirlwind rollercoaster across Isla Sorna. As more and more characters begin to die off through a variety of prehistoric means the novel easily distances its self from the movie bearing the same name all the way up the explosive ending. All in this entire novel would deserve a 6 as the second half of the novel puts the items discussed in the first half of the novel into perspective. However as Amazon does not have the ability to rate out of 6 stars it will have to do with a 5.

On re-reading Jurassic Park eight years after its first publication, I found it was just as pretty damn' good as I had remembered it to be. Whether or not the actual science is plausible and that chunks of dino DNA  can be reconstituted, like so many packets of ancient powdered soup (I like  to think it will be possible, eventually!) Michael Crichton writes a  first-rate disaster story. My favourite moment now is when Muldoon is down  in the garage (inspecting the jeep that the ill-fated Nedry is going to  steal later,) and hears the first rumbles of thunder in the distance; this  is just before the whole shebang slides into chaos, and re-reading it sent  a delicious shiver down my spine. Wonderful stuff.. It is also clear that  when describing the antics of biotech companies, Crichton was right on the  money. Okay, so a genetically modified canola oil plant is somewhat less  spectacular than a full-grown T-Rex; however, scratch the surface of  today's aggressive purveyors of patented veggies, and you'll probably find  the same macho attitude displayed by InGen and Biosyn in the novel (which  is lambasted at length by chaos theorist Ian Malcolm.) So, both exciting  and relevant - if you still haven't read it yet, I would urge you to do so  without further delay!

This is less a review of the book than a commentary on the comparison of book and movie. A lot of people think the book is a lot better than the movie, but I think that's an unfair judgement. You can't compare movies and books! They each have different strengths and weaknesses. The movie was great, but if the novel followed the movie, it would be a boring, simplistic book. The book was great, but if the movie was absolutely faihtful to the book, it would have been an extremely long, boring, and confusing movie. You have to understand that books and movies are two very dissimilar media that should not be compared. Books provide insight into characters' feelings and motivations, while movies can't really do that and be exciting at the same time. There are just some things that are hard or impossible to do in a movie that are easy to do in a book. Judge movies and their books separately, because they have different purposes and are completely different art forms. The fact that someone enjoyed one more than the other doesn't mean one is BETTER than the other. A movie-lover would like the movie more, and a book-lover would like the book more. Keep this in mind before you say one is better than the other

The details in this novel are amazing and the ideas of cloning, especially from insects in amber, are brilliant! Being related to a grandfather with money and OCD eccentricity; I could vividly see the tantrums and fits about instant gratification and the fact that he (Mr. Hammond) would let no one thwart his dream! Mr. Hammond has bought an island in a country that doesn't censure everything that people do. So far Hammond has lived his dreams by building a park like no other in the world; a dinosaur park! On the day he brings some scientists in to get their input, possibly listen to their ideas, and has his own two grandchildren visit for this first tour: everyone is in awe!!! A short time later, an employee decides to commit corporate espionage and everything goes quickly downhill from there. Imagine fleeing for your life from terrifying dinosaurs while you wait for backup and medical help. All this and so much more is in this book. I loved it so much more than the movie!

Having seen the film, I thought I was familiar with the book. WRONG. This excellent novel stands on its own and I can't help but wonder how the film would've been if they had stuck to the book. I love the book. No romance and sentiment, and the little girl is annoying as hell. Crichton really has a flair for storytelling and backs it up with the necessary science to boot. John Hammond is an elitist snob who gets his comeuppance, a major change from Spielberg's film. The film kept some of the storyline and only a few characters and made the rest family-friendly. The Book stands on it's own as a work of art and one hell of a book. I'm surprised that there is no audio book version of this work, as there is one for the sequel The Lost World. Whether you have seen the film or not you definitely should read Jurassic Park. So many of the themes still ring true in this day and age. So good, I will have to read it again! A must have for any collection.

Well, it took almost 7 years, but I finally gave into the hype and bought JP and devoured it (no pun intended) in a matter of days.  Nearly all books are better than their movie-counterparts, but very few are as different  from their movie-counterparts as this one.  It took Spielberg a year or two  to make the movie.  But I made a ten-times better movie within a week or  two by reading this book and conjuring up images no special effects studio  could ever muster.  And actually, I'm kinda glad the movie was so  different.  Because when reading the book, I was totally clueless as to  what was going to happen next.  Who gets killed and eaten?  How does Grant  and the kids get out of this dilemma?  And so on...  But the most ingenious  part of this novel is the risk that Mr. Crichton takes at the end of the  book, a risk that very few writers are ever courageous enough to take:  he  ends the book just as the reader is begging for more.

I'm not gonna say the plot because just about everyone has heard about Jurassic Park.  All I'm going to say is that as one of the gods of Science Fiction writing, Michael Crichton's books have been remarkable in that they take seemingly improbable situations and convert them into scenarios that are very believable.  He does it once again with Jurassic Park. Crichton ingeniously interweaves details of genetic engineering, computer wizardry and current scientific controversy over dinosaurs to fashion an amazing read.  In most cases, the book is much better than the movie as there are many, many scenes that didn't make it to the movie.  Some being: The Pteradactyl showdown, the compys, Gennaro's hunt with Muldoon, the T-Rex's baby, and much more.  There are even characters that died/lived in book that died/lived in the movie!  I can't say enough good things about the book so just go out, read it, and be amazed!

I'll try to stay away from making judgements about whether or not the book is better than the film or vice versa.  The reason being that the film obviously had a different aim than the book.  A strict translation of the book would have yielded a film with an R rating.  The book has more suspense, more action, death and dinosaurs.  While not extremely graphic, the book is clearly more violent than the feature film.  Also, the book goes into much more detail about the science behind the discovery of the scientists in the book.  This is a trademark of all Crichton novels - one of the reasons I find his books so fascinating.  At times it can get frustrating as the science is beyond my understanding, but it does not detract from the overall enjoyment of the book.  I have read most, but not all, of Crichton's novels, and this particular novel is second only toCongo.  A terrific novel that should not be missed.

I liked this novel a lot.  It was just as good as the movie, and I saw the movie before I read the book, so I already had most of the characters in my head, and I luckily got to vividly see how realistic the dinosaurs were! The only downside is that the veloceraptors kill to many people, and the big tyrannosaurus rex ate NO ONE.  But the scene where they had to go on the raft was very interesting and scary none the less.  I liked how descriptive Michael Crichton was in writing the book, and how he described the dinosaurs, to make them appear so real to the readers.  The movie was totally AWESOME, too.  I am a BIG Steven Spielberg fan! Overall, this book was fast-paced and action-packed, a real page turner! Could have gone without so much technical mumbo-jumbo, though.  Great work Mr. Crichton, one of your best!
It was so scientific and it brought back memorys of when i was into dinosaurs. Absolutely thrilling from start to end.

I love Dennis Nedry.  That's the only reason I bought the book.  The problem Nedry faced is the same problem every nerd on the planet faces.  When a nerd tries something involving a significant amount of risk or worldly experience, disaster is the only result.  Just stay at your workstation if you are a geek or a nerd.  You'll live to a ripe old age if you do.  Nedry and Arnold show you how not to do it.  The sweet thing is that John Hammond gets killed, too.  Anyway, realize that if you are a geek or a nerd, you should have your head glued to a monitor rather than take the risks that more competent people routinely face.  That's the big lesson the book imparts other than demonstrating that Michael Crichton has no idea what real computer code looks like.

I laugh when I read all of these reviews saying that he is wrong about dinosaur behaviour.  There is a particularly amusing (and long) letter  nearer the bottom of the reviews.  He recomends a book by some guy who  "knows what he`s talking about".  Uh-huh?  Are we to beleive that  because this guy is a paleontologist that what he says is gospel?  Good one  mate.  How does he know that the dinosaur will sit for hours mourning the  loss of her partner?  He doesn`t.  Nobody does.  Maybe Michael Crichton has  written the most accurate portrayal of dinosaur life known (or unknown) to  man.  So why don`t people read the book, enjoy it for what it is and stop  critisicing the facts he presents.

I have to admit, I bought this book about 10 years after the film was released, so I was pretty slow to get started...and now I'm sorry I left it so long. This book is a masterpiece, a truly brilliant adventure. This book has set the standards for fantasy/science-fiction/adventure books forever. Crichton has quite clearly done some background digging, but whilst doing this incorporated his own ideas to create a fresh, realistic story. The way he words things, the descriptions of the characters and dinosaurs and the extensive insight into genetic cloning at the begining all add to the final touch, and ultimately make this novel totally believable. I would recommend this book to anyone.
coming from a non-reader, this book hooked me into reading.  it is much better than the movie

This book combines drama and suspense with science and a certain amount of moralizing. The book's major premise-using the DNA of long extinct species-is clever because it is so believable and thus frightening. The book plays upon the idea that if one tampers with Nature's most sacred mechanisms, there will be a price to pay and dangers that one can neither anticipate nor accomodate. The idea of a Caribbean park featuring such resurrected creatures provides a macabre and riveting fascination. The book and movie have been out for a while but nevertheless, if you haven't read this, it is still a good read.

If you have ever had a fascination with dinosaurs anywhere along the line of your life, then you will love this book.  I saw the movie first, and I was impressed.  When I read the book about 4 months later, I was blown  away. The movie left out some sequences that would have been just  incredible for the movie!!!!!!  This book is a fine example of creativity  and knowledge in a field.  This book made me a Crichton fan.  No one has  ever used such detail in describing a dinosaur in a work of fiction that I  have read (and I've read a lot of 'em). I can't wait for a follow-up to the  Lost World!

Jurassic Park is a fantastic science fiction book that goes well beyond  the dinosaur-eats-man simpleness of its movie counterpart. Far from even  mentioning dinosaurs in the first chapters, it also delves deep into the  unseen orders and designs of twisting Mother Nature's original plans. The  dinosaurs in this book are not dull-witted, slow, or even an obnoxious  shade of purple. They all are learning, living creatures that are starting  to show humankind that you can take dinosaurs out of the past but not the  past out of the dinosaur. Simply stunning, and painstakingly accurate to  boot.

Jurassic Park is a great book. If you saw the movie, then you have to read the book. It is so much better. While in the movie things seem to just happen, the book describes scenes and characters with more details The  story is told with a lot of realism, and while you read you can almost  picture the dinosaurs running around. Some examples of detail include how  the dinosaurs attack, and there is blood and guts described, such as limbs  being torn off and stomachs being slashed. All this is tied together with a  great ending. If you read this, then also read its sequel, The Lost World.

The embodiment of Hard Science is in a character in J.P. named Ian Malcom whose farsightedness is a pure delight whenever he speaks in the novel.  I especially enjoyed his, "..life will find a way.." speech.  The  plot is a tightly wound ball of string that as you read on begins to  unravel until everything and everyone is engulfed in utter chaos.  Another  of Malcom's enjoyable speeches is on the nature of chaos.  A very important  work, that should have won a pulitzer.  A little different from my style,  though, so four instead of five stars will do.

This is one of the few books, I have reread many times.  My personal copy of this book is dog-eared and wrinkled, due to so much reuse.  The book, though fiction, is quasi-based on some very good biology, which makes it that much more entertaining.  It is action packed, and full of great character development.  Michael Crichton is a great author, and in my personal opinion this is one of his better books.  I highly recommend this book to anyone looking for a good book and some high class entertainment.  Just beware, this is a very hard book to put down.

Jurassic Park is one of my favorite books! It has a lot of action and a lot of descriptions. The story is very similar to the ever famous Jurassic Park movie by Stephen Spielberg { sp? sorry } The terror and action the Crichton creates with the dinosaur chases is very thrilling. There are some parts where you think, what just happend? And then you have to reread it again. But all in all it's a very great book and I would recommend that you would read Lost World Jurassic Park and that you watch all three of the Jurassics because their all great!

Crichton does it again with another great book.  This has to be one of the greatest books I have ever read.  There are almost no words to describe it.  If you saw the movie, pick this book up.  If you did not, pick this book up.  If you do not even like dinosaurs get this book.  The amount of time Crichton puts into his work is amazing.  The only thing I can say is if you read this, do not read the sequel.  It is not nearly as good, and it is a sequel to the movie not the book.  Overall, this will keep you reading from cover to cover nonstop.

I(decided to reread this book and I was glad I did. I had nothing else to read and I read this book when it first came out  23 or so years ago., that makes me feel old lol.  I had forgotten most of the book  so for the most part it seemed like a new one.  My only complain is that I was not wild about the little girl character, very annoying and  also  checking on the eggs  at the end of the book did not make sense.  I thought the girl in the movie was better written. It is a shame that he is no longer around-was a good writer.

I have been a fan of the movies since they came out and have them memorized.  That said, the book read a lot different than the movies, for which I am glad.  I knew the book would be different but didn't see a need to read it.  Am I glad I did. The typos are throughout, just a little FYI.  But all in all, a great book to sit and relax with.  I was asked which I liked better, the movie or the book.  The movie seemed a bit campy and the book edgier.  I have no preference, but am glad I took the time to finally read this one.

I originally chose to read this book because I was a Jurassic Park(movie) enthusiast. I figured the novel would be different than the movie(of course), but only with minor details. I was so wrong! I found myself turning my head and cringing by some of the awesome graphic detail. It was like diving into a new world of dinosaurs all over again. My only criticism is that there is quite a lot of genetic mumbo jumbo which didn't interest me. Although those details were not for me, I would definitely recommend this novel!

Jurassic Park starts when John Hammond, the wealthy owner of Ingen, a biotech company, invites an assortment of people to visit his new resort to test it out, but it turns out that is really a dinosaur zoo.  The excitement really starts when the park loses power, and the dinosaurs are set free!  From here the people get separated, and try to find each other while they get the park running. In the end they escape with the help of the government.  A thrilling, rocket speed, edge of your seat book.

In comparing this book to others in the same genre it is difficult to not find it spectacular. The characters are well developed, the story is plausable to the genre and the era it is set in, and this book has a  message. The author tells a story that has meaning down to this day. What  better way for a book to last if it can be used and enjoyed for  generations? Superb work by Crichton and should be considered one of the  greatest sci-fi books of our lifetime.

Jurassic Park was a good book but it could have been better. I liked the book and I must say it was way better then the movie. The book was much more action paced then the movie and explaned a lot more, but was missing  somethings that would have made it better to me. I'm not going to spoil the  end which is where I think the book could have made some changes. Overall I  was glued to the book.I recommend this book to anyone that would like a  good book.

Loved this book ever since I first read it in high school in '91. As a young kid who grew up loving dinosaurs and wanting to be a paleontologist, this book fulfilled all my dreams of wanting to see a live dinosaur. Crichton is such a masterful writer and I think I read this in less than two or three days. The pace was quick and the detail was engrossing. Still one of my all time favorite books that I can read over and over again.

Jurassic Park has breathtaking action, detail and characters. I would give it 5 stars except for one drawback. The book is kind of bogged down with Malcom's speeches about chaos theory but moreover his endless lectures about how much he hates the human race and how terrible we are. Jurassic Park is 3/4 action novel the other 1/4 is Malcom's jabbering.  Fortunately if you can look past this small problem the book is great. ...

My nine year old dinosaur obsessed son loved this book. Although it is technically for adults, he is a slightly mature reader, and was able to comprehend the plot with no problem. I am sure it helped that he has seen the movie many times! He was also able to discern some differences between the book and the movie. One more thing to note, the language was mostly appropriate (TV-type language). He thoroughly enjoyed it.

It was truly a very exciting book.  It was exciting and interesting throughout the entire book.  I just couldn't put it down.  It never seemed to get boring at all.  Even when it did it wasn't really boring, it just slowed down a bit to give more information on what was going on.  It was always a needed part of the story so it wasn't really boring.  It is a book that I would read again and enjoy many times.

this was my first crichton book i read thinking the movie was good the book should be good. The book was so much better than the movie it made the effects  look like claymation.Much more detailed and descriptive.( if you  dont like gory stuff  you might not like it) it was my first crichton and i  havnt been able to stop reading  his books!I read AIRFRAME it two  days!  Some advice BUY THE BOOK NOW!

Michael Cricheon is one of the rare writers who can provide ultra realism in his science fiction without sacrificing the story or losing the reader in the science.  He's really raised the standard of science fiction.  Few writers compare to him and Jurassic Park is one of his best novels.  This is the story of the humans, not the dinosaurs, and it's realistic, well thought  out and satisfying.

I've read the majority of Crichton's works, and this one takes the cake, as they say. I've read this book three times over the years, and it never fails to entertain. And, for the record, it blows the movie away. The  combination of science and science fiction is very well done, and there is  no shortage of action to keep the reader interested. A page-turner to the  end!

If you have seen the movie and have not read the book, you should make it your first priority to read it. This book is 10 times better than the movie, and I thought the movie was amazing. I really enjoyed this book and thought it to be one of Crichton's best.  His scientific knowledge and imagination takes you on another wild ride through the Jurrasic age when dinosaurs lived.  Throwing in Ian Malcom's chaos theory really did wonders for the mind.  I loved this book and it's compelling so I reccommend it to others as a must read book
The book is so much better than the movie.  After all of these years this is still one of my favorites.
This is by far one of the best books ever! I would highly recomend this book to anyone who is looking for a great book! The movie was amazing but, the book was even better!

This is the book that Spielberg tried to adapt into a movie, not that the film is bad, but the book is way better and also very different.  This has been a favorite of mine since it first came out in paperback (which thankfully no longer has to take my abuse since I now have a kindle to read it on, I'm surprised  that it has survived all the years). There are things that we're cut out or changed around because movies are inherently different, the book explains everything so much better.

But I liked the details of the book about genetic innovation and the dangers of systemic failure that the book goes into. The movie is scarier, but the book is a better than expected intellectual read.
I read it as a kid and I wanted to re read it. Classic book and you must read it.

Much more happens in the book than the movie.  I re-read this for the first time in about 20 years.  The only things I didn't like we're the bits that seemed illogical, and it also has a pretty slow start.  Worth the wait.
This book was so much better than the movie, so much detail. The movie was great but the was better.
Better than the movie. Intense and in-depth. I recommend to anyone looking for a great sci-fi/action-adventure read. I was engaged from start to finish.

The adaptation they made already is great in its own right but I do think that staying true to the book would be just as amazing.  Good thing we live in a time a revamps, prequels, sequels, & second chances.  But please try not to make the little girl as annoying and incomprehensible as she was here.  NO child is that clueless.
honestly I enjoyed the book more than the movie but if you are a fan of the movie you will definitely like the book I will not spoil anything just read it
I enjoyed this as a kid. I think I liked it even more this recent time. I might just read it again...
Liked the movie, loved the book. Way better ending and cliff hanger to lead in to the sequel. Also, it wasn't all about the rex as the movie was.
The third time I've read Jurassic Park, and each time I find something new and different. A novel  and unique book.

I remember reading this book as a child and I absolutely loved it. The characters are what make this book great, let's not forget the dinosaurs. I loved the way the author describes them to the reader. A must read !

This book far exceeded my expectations.... Crichton was definitely a talented writer.  I grew up watching the jurassic park films and finally decided to read the book.... I definitely recommend this book!!!
I have loved the movie ever since I had first seen it and the book was exactly what I had hoped for!

I first read this book many years ago when the movie first came out.  I was disappointed in it then. But now as an adult I have  to say it was a gripping tail of adventure and a chilling warning of.what science could do.  A must read on every ones reading list
I love this book.  I read it many years ago and when I heard the movie was coming out on 3D I decided to read it again.  Love it.
Got this because my older son loves Jurassic Park. It is great for him because he can take the kindle and read it anywhere.
this book is totally different from the movie. I wish the movie had a lot of the scenes The book does.I  appreciate it that the book and  movie had the same characters names
I've seen all the Jurassic Park movies and absolutely love them, but so far the book is better. Its more gory and just keeps you wanting more.

What can one say about Jurassic Park? It's fantastic. In my opinion, it is Michael Crichton's best book, and I've read them all. Excellent story, characters, and action, and, of course, plenty of blood and death! This isn't just my favorite MC book, it shares the spot of my favorite book of all time (along with Harry Potter). I have read this book multiple times, and I never get tired of it. The day JP was finally available for Kindle, I bought it. If you enjoy a thriller, you can't go wrong with this. Even if you don't enjoy a thriller... you might start after this book!
I saw the movie first and loved it. I was told to read the book and thought it could not live up to the beauty of the movie. I was wrong - this book is great and one of my all time favorites.

Information is what held this book together for me. The information about chaos theory and how that applies. Learning about paleontologist theories being applied to a level of genius. The book kept you interested not for the intense parts or the many lines of detail, but of the amount of information that was strung across the book.
The book still holds up.  I didn't get bored, but I think the book was a little wordy.  It didn't flow that well.
The book was great and Jurassic park is the longest and the best book I have ever read. I hope to read the next book of the series the lost world.

This was the first Michael Crichton book I ever read, and it continues to be one of my favorites.  The movie, although good in its Hollywood appeal-to-the-masses way, simply can't compare.  The novel is darker and more suspenseful, the characters and backstory are more developed, the moral questions are more obvious, the science is fleshed out more, and my personal favorite, Malcolm's rants on theory, are more numerous and in-depth.  There are also a lot more human-dinosaur interactions, which is inevitable considering the expense and technical difficulty of CGI when the movie was made, but those interactions are, in my opinion, the lifeblood of the story.  The friendly, appealing baby dinosaurs provide an emotional counterpoint to the dangerous adults, making the ending much more poignant.
Its simple: the movie is nice, but the book is exceptional. The description of the scenes exceed by far the scenes of the movie. Buy it and love it!
Jurassic Park is about people who get trapped on an island that is infested with dinosaurs. I highly recommend this book to ages 15 and up.
So much supense in the story, and fascinating description. truly a classic piece of literature. nothing like the film. consider teading the book. seriously
This book is great!  One book that everyone should read.  As always Micheal Crichton knows how to tell a story.  Even if you have already read this as a child it is still great as an adult!

This book was amazing and I recommend it to anybody 10 and up. It was better than the movie and very different. Very descriptive and sometimes too descriptive (graphic guts and gore). This tale is one of the best books and a classic at its best. I`m on Lost World and it`s as interesting as its brother. Dinos are awesome!

In sharp contrast to the movie, this book is extremely deep and you can really get into it. Ian Malcolm is a much better developed character in the book, and the rants due to the morphine he's on are especially powerful.  Only problem is, I read it so often, my paperbacks keep falling apart, so i  have to buy more. =)

This is one of the best books i have ever read, and believe me i read a lot! It is a mixture of scientific-genetic sort of theme and of course the classic dinosoar-tearing-apart-humans theme. It is very suspensful and I couldn't put it down. I would recommend it to anyone looking for a good read.

Much different than the movie. It's a good read much darker than the movie as well. A few more people die. It also comes across a bit preachy on the evils of science and genetic research. Worth reading but I was hoping it would be a little more exciting than I feel it actually turned out to be.

So clever, moved so quickly.  Agree that characters are indeed "stick figures" as many critics alleged, but still, dinosaurs alive now - today ... just really, really cool!  The fact that it's supported by detailed, realistic science makes it very believable.  A lot of fun!

Fantastic story, fast and heart pumping, nail biting action, Dinosaurs! It's also a cautionary tale about what happens when greed, corporate biasery and a desire to play God mix up together. Obviously all sorts of horrible things at once. Be prepared to run for your life!

i really loved the book. critchton has qiete an imagination.i already read it 2 times. and the 2 book once, but im going to read the second one again.the charactors were the best names and the dinosaurs are really scary . you cant even put the book down. its very dramatic

Great story.  My complaint is with the construction of the book.  The hardcover version is easily the worst quality hardcover book I've ever purchased.  The cover is extremely thin corregated cardboard.  The paper is low quality.  Hardcover ain't what it used to be.

I am pretty much obsessed with Jurassic Park and having grown up with the movie(s), i watched it before i had even thought of the book. Thankfully i can finally say i've seen it and read the book. I love both and would tell anyone and everyone to read the book.

I love the movies and found out recently they were books first.  I had no clue lol I very much enjoyed reading the book version better than watching the movie.  I am about to read them again bc I liked them so much.  Recommended for all Jurassic Park lovers.

I've read most of Michael Crichton's books, (Sphere, Jurassic Park, The Lost World, Terminal Man, The Andromeda Strain, Timeline, and Airframe)and this has to be his best!  I found it to be way better than the movie.  Just  gold!  This is the book to read!

I really loved the movie and was so excited to finally read the boom.  This book was great, there was so much more character development than the movie.  Great dinosaurs also and the science was explained very simply.  The book was a fun, exciting read.

I don't know why I wanted to read this book but I'm glad I did. I've seen the movie so I was interested to see the book differed. It was such a good read. I didn't want to put it down. I've recommended it to a few of my friends before I was even done.

Jurassic Park was a excellent, well-written book.  Iliked tis book because it was realistic, descriptive, and teaches a lesson.  It's very realistic, so realistic it's terrifying.  An example of this is when the scientists  take dinosaur DNA from blood and clone it.  I can actually see scientists,  in real life doing this an creating prehistoric animals.  Another realistic  part was how the dinosaurs managed to breed even though it was supposed to  be impossible.  The dinosaurs were all made females, but the geneticists  made the mistake of using DNA from animals with the ability to change their  gender.  So the dinosaurs were breeding and no one knew about it.  This was  a believeable explination of how the dinosaurs were able to breed.  Another factor that made this novel good, was its being very descriptive.  The way Crichton describes the velociraptors seem smarter and scarier than  they were in the movie.  These dinosaurs could create and execute plans  working together.  They could also run, jump, hide, and slash people open  with these giant claws on their feet.  The Tyrannosaurus was also scary  dinosaur, but it was also sort of stupid.  The velociraptors were better  than it.  For one thing, the T-rex could only see her prey if it was  moving.  Also it was a solitary hunter that didn't and couldn't hide.  And  the only plan it could execute was chase a herd of smaller dinosaurs and  hope to snacth a weakling or a baby.  Anyway, the novel was very  descriptive (it gave me an opinion on the best preditor, which happens to  be the velociraptor).  One thing about life that I learned from this  novel is that people can't control it.  The creators of Jurassic Park  expected to be able to control and handle nature.  They thought they could  keep the animals from breeding, of course they failed but, that didn't stop  the people.  When the finally realized they were wrong about controlling  nature and life, it was too late for them and may other people (if you know  what I mean).  For all of these reasons, Jurassic Park is a great book.  It is one of the few truly frightening books I've ever read, and yes, it's  better than the movie.

I began this book with the expectation that it would be as remarkable as the movie, but what I got was 100 times better! The book holds its own even 20 years later; both in technological intelligence, and suspense filled adventure.

This novel is more intense than I expected, with psychological thriller elements. I would recommend reading Jurassic Park--it is layered and complex, and astonishing to someone who had no idea that the movie was originally a book.

This book is very entertaining. If you enjoy thrillers and action this is the book for you. I read this for school and ended up reading the second book in the series because I enjoyed it so much. This is a great read for anyone

I literally finished this book in a weekend. I loved it--and I'm not the biggest sci-fi fan either. Honestly thought it had much richer detail than the movie (especially the part with the mini-Elephant, so want one of those!).

A classic!  Whether it's the action, the thrilling pacing, or the expert reasoning of Ian Malcolm, you always have a reason to turn the next page.  The movie is great, the book is fantastic.  Especially at this Kindle price.

This is one of the best science fiction novels ever. Michael Crichton was a fantastic writer in technical matters which he translated for everyday lay people. As usual, he mixed high drama with fantastic scientific clarity.

This is arguably the best Michael Crichton book ever! The story, revolving around a group of people trapped in an amusement park with no power and man-eating dinosaurs is kind of a combination of already invented themes,  but none were ever executed so intelligently. Most of us know the story, so  I won't go too much in detail. Dr. Grant and Ellie Sattler, scientists,  visit Jurassic Park. With them are fellow scientists, engineers, and the  old eccentric who created the park, John Hammond. When a planned  power-outage goes wrong during the visit, tourists are trapped in the  middle of the park with the dinosaurs, and the rest at the Visitor's Center  are practically in a beseiged fortress. Like most great authors, whether  Crichton intended it or not, his morals got into the book. All of the  "villains" of the book die because of their sins, or rather, the  people who created the park die, and Ian Malcolm, who spends much of the  book half-dead, preaches to the others about what did go wrong and what is  wrong with the world and what should be done about it, naturally with the  "correct" solutions. I did agree with them, but it was the  author's opinion. And at the hands of these scientists and engineers who  created the park, several others meet a horrible fate. The ending wasn't  meant to be cheerful, but this book left me with more than a visit to an  already fascinating island of horror and fantasy. Michael Crichton really  outdid himself when he wrote this book, and I have yet to meet someone who  didn't like it.
