This is one of my favorite books of all time. It is such a great thriller, with great characters and very intense action. If you are a fan of Jurassic Park, you have to read this book. (I recommend the Lost World as well.)

Science fiction is not my thing.  I read this book as a requirement of a summer reading program.  The detail of the book made the story far more interesting than the movie.  It was readable for me, which is saying a lot.

I am reading this book for a high school independant reading asignment. Yes, i have seen the movie and i thought it was a good but after reading the book i have a whole new view of it. I picked up this book thinking thinking it would be just like the movie and i could blow through it, but as i began to read I became sucked into the fictional world of "Jurassic Park". The book starts out setting up readers with some interesting scences that imediatly draw your attention. As the book continues to unfold one cannot help themselves but to not put down the book. The creativity that was put into the book was just great. I thought all the scientific reasonings behind the recreation of the Dinosaurs was brilliant. I also thought the plot behind the book was well thought out and nicely set up by Crichton. The story truely begins to unfold when a group of people including a lawyer, Mathmatician, and Archeologist discover that these dinosaurs (which were never meant to be able to breed) have somehow began to breed themselves on the island without anyone even knowing. With that being one of the many twist and turns throughout this book I just couldnt put down this book and i enjoyed every single minute that i spent reading this book. With that being said I would highly recommend this book to anyone, I know lots of people probably see this book and just think, "oh ive seen the movie im not going to read that" well thats what i thought to, but after reading it i'm happy to say that i'm glad with my choice. 5 stars, two thumbs up

Book came within four days in perfect condition! Book is amazing! if you haven't read this book then you definitely should check it out. The movies are amazing but the book is great because it gives you so much more!

I ordered this book after my son attempted to purchase it at a local chain bookstore and it wasn't availible. To order it in , it would have been quadruple the price! The book arrived quickly and in great shape. Ty!

I'm Matt McGovern, 12 years old from Louisiana. I read this about a week ago and i was astounded.I was thinking, you know: With this stuff on the market, why the hell is RL Stine getting so much credit! You know?

I recommend this book, Jurassic Park by Michael Crichton, to anyone that loves adventure, suspense, and most of all dinosaurs. If you are looking for a good book that will keep you reading then this is it. Jurassic Park is about this theme park called Jurassic Park, located on an island, created and owned by John Hammond. Hammond is the CEO and founder of InGen, a company that has figured out how to mix dinosaur DNA with frog DNA to essentially bringing them back from the dead. He plans to showcase the dinosaurs in this theme park and have people tour it. He invites paleontologists Alan Grant, Ellie Sattler (Alan’s grad student), mathematician Ian Malcolm, and his two grandchildren to tour the park before opening. In the middle of the tour something happens, something bad. Throughout the whole book I wanted to keep reading. The adventure starts when they get to the island. All of the characters are described well enough so it is like you’re getting to know them. The dinosaurs are described nicely, as well, so you can easily picture the theme park. As you are reading you slowly get immersed into the park more and more so you might get a feel of what kind of situation one of the characters might be in. The suspense is one of the major things keeping you reading though. You will not want to put the book down until the thing ends or is resolved but right when it does and new thing pops up, keeping you reading and immersed into their world.
I like that the book is quite darker than the movie. Several other little twists that differ as well.  The operation of the park and the creation of the dinosaurs fascinated me.  Highly recommended.

First, let me preach the scientific inaccuracies of this book.  From a paleontological standpoint, much of dinosaur behavior and movement is based on pure assumption on Crichton's part.  The Dilophosaurus poison thing can be overlooked, as can the double-sized Velociraptors.  I don't appreciate Crichton's half-research on dinosaurs and I think the T-rex's movement based vision was a flaring idiotic idea.  Otherwise, the characters, as in almost all of Crichton's literature, were fairly shallow.  Also, how did the Jurassic Park scientists move the embryo to the egg?  Crichton himself admits he neglected to include this in his novel because he couldn't figure out a way around it. But enough griping.  Let's address what was spectacular about this novel.  The plot was mastermind, and the action overall is superior to Crichton's other books.  The elements of suspense Crichton includes show Crichton's great skill at writing contemporary fiction.  It's too bad that this was the last novel Crichton wrote as a story to be told instead of a book to be easily developed into a screenplay for a movie.  Plot is a ten but character underdevelopment, scientific assumptions, paleontological guesses, and half-hearted unresearched references to Chaos Theory (a theory that I put stock in, its just that Crichton obviously fails to do it justice) bring my rating down to an eight.

The world Jurassic was simply gibberish until Crichton touched it and brought new life to the concept of dinosaur fiction and biomedical technology.  The book and movie were mammoth in popularity when the novel and movie was first conceptualized over twenty years ago.  I remember asking for the book in the children's library around the corner from my house and I pronounced Crichton wrong and the strange word Jurassic correctly.  Everyone wanted to be a paleontologist when they grew up back in those days just because of the book and it really made both children and adults excited about reading as well as science and technology.  Crichton, was an MD and created the show E.R. also, this is a great example for writers and scientists alike because Crichton tried to maximize his potential.  My favorite part of the book was when they first arrived on the remote island and they were describing the mysterious and suspenseful premise of how the dinosaurs were created from ancient DNA found inside a mosquito that had bitten a dinosaur and from the bones of dinosaur fossils.  The most exciting and exhilarating part of the movie was when they finally escaped in the end but the heart skips a beat when you realize that some flying dinosaurs escaped the island as well!  The DNA technology used in the book is technically possible through cloning techniques.
A very enjoyable book with great action, only waxes philosophical a couple of times. There are similar things to the awesome movie, but this is the original and I think it does the story best.
The book is far better than the motion picture in that it goes into greater detail about the characters and the situation.  I read it in one sitting ... hope you enjoy it as much as I did.

The first time I had read Jurassic Park was in 7th grade, only last year.  I had a hard time understanding it because the book can be quite technical.  But I loved the action.  I just finnished it a couple of days ago and I had understood it much better.  Michael Chrichton is one of the best  authors I have seen.  He really takes the reader into the book.  I felt  like I was actually in Jurassic Park, rather than reading about it.  It's a  wonderful sensation.  The charactors that he describes almost seem real.  I  would definitely chose this books over regular dinosaur or science fiction  books.  Some people would say that the movie of Jurassic Park is better  than the book. Personaly, I disagree.  The book is so much beter than the  movie; hands down!  When you read it, you feel scared.  Scared as in the  dinosaurs are going to eat you.  While reading, I looked at the raptors,  streight in the eyes.  I could smell their fetid stench.  You can't do that  in the movie.  So, in concusion, I would like to say that Jurassic Park  is one of the best books that I have read.  Michael Chrichton is a  wonderful author and in just one page of his books, he can teach you about  dinosaurs, humanity, anything.  If I had to read any book in the world for  a project, I would definitelly chose this one.

Something's coming. A new idea of bringing back the past, an idea that could turn the world into total chaos.  A new technique has been formed to extract dinosaur DNA, allowing blood cells to form. Those blood cells, mixed with other materials, formed our greatest fear: dinosaurs. InGen has discovered a way to create the extinct creatures and form an amusment park with them as the main attractions. InGen's owner, John Hammond, invited Ian Malcom (a mathematician), two well known paleontologists, a lawyer, and the manager of InGen to an island off the coast of Costa Rica. On this island lays Jurassic Park.  Experiencing the presence of these dinos is all too thrilling, until a storm knocks off the power with the help of Dennis Nedry, a computer expert. One-by-one the carnivorous dinosaurs eat off the visitors until only a handful are left. The T-Rexes loose in the park is a big problem, but a bigger one is the raptors. What will happoen in this world of total chaos? The world of chaos known as Jurassic Park.....  If you love horror and thrilling scientific fiction, you'll adore "Jurassic Park" by Micheal Crichton. It's highly suspensful and you can't put it down until the end. It's the most thrilling book I've ever read. It's called "Jurassic Park".

Anybody who is a fan of techno-thrillers must read this book! Crichton puts on a good show for the millions of fans he has around the world with this great novel. I saw the movie first, and if you were like me and  thought that the movie was excellent, you should really read this book!  Crichton fills this book with horror, action, suspense, and imagination. He  also fills it with his personal ideas through the character of Ian Malcolm.  His ideas of the dinosaurs are clever and for the most part accurate. Not  everybody can come up with a good theory on the behavior of dinosaurs, and  I think Crichton took that challenge head on and succeeded! His personal  view on the behavior of the velociraptors in the book is as close as  anybody can get with the limited information that the world has on  dinosaurs. This book is fascinating through and through and I found it hard  to put it down, which I believe that you will do also. If you like  thrillers or suspense novels, or just a good book to read, I suggest you  pick up this page-turner and see for yourselves how imaginative this book  truly is. I am sure you will find that this book is as good as I say it is.  But don't take my word for it, see for yourselves! This book was, and still  is, an absolute thrill ride from start to finish.
I saw the movie a few years ago and was amazed at how realistic the dinosaurs looked. I finally read the book recently, and in my opinion it's better than the movie. Very suspenseful.

This is indeed an exciting and suspenseful book.  There is a great amount of detail in the book.  Sometimes the detail us unnecessary to the point of becoming boring, but over all it gave the book an addictive allure that was hard to put down.  Now, I  assuming that most of you who are interested is reading the book Jurassic Park have seen the movie Jurassic Park.  In most cases the book is far better then the movie, as the movies is made to be exciting and have good special effects while the book ha a good plot.  In this case the movie was quite good.  The movie was more for children while the book is more properly suited for mature readers.  Obviously, when the book was made into a movie some changes were made.  What I noticed most were the change made to the character.  For example John Hammond is not the misguided loving grandfather that he is in Jurassic Park the movie.  Instead he is a stubborn man blinded by greed.  "The goal here is to make money.  Lots of money."  said Hammond.  Ironically n the movie the lawyer Gennaro is a greed corporate attorney and Hammond is the loveable grandfather.  In the book Gennaro is the honest man while Hammond is the greedy one.  Over all it is a good book with a good deal of action and a large amount of detail.
I read Jurassic Park every couple of years and always enjoy it. It is well written and even though it was written more than 20 years ago is still applicable to current science.

This is simply the best book I have ever read! That might seem a little extreme, but it was awesome. Sure, it may be unrealistic, but that's part of what made it so great. I think everyone knows the plot, so I won't waste time with that.  It was so exciting and suspenseful. Every action sequence was truly wonderful. The only word I can use to describe this book is amazing. The movie, at first glance, was amazing. The special effects were revolutionary. But the book was so much better. Compared to the book, the movie had almost no action. My only problem was that it was too short. The first time I read it I was only like 7 or 8, and it took me a few months to read. But the second time I read it I was 11 or 12 and I read it in two days. I would've loved to see this be a 1,000+ page epic. But then it would probably still be too short for me. People who enjoyed this book as much as I did might not want to read the sequel, The Lost World. It didn't have nearly as much action as JP. Although the last hundred pages of LW are almost worthy of its predecessor, the rest falls short. In conclusion, this is the book for anyone who enjoys exciting suspenseful books about creatures or wild predators and who aren't offset by unrealistic plots.
Worth the read, nicely written book with distinct and fascinating characters as well as details that you may not have thought part of this story if you just watched the movie.
Did anyone read this and NOT want Lex to get eaten? Seriously from start to finish that's all I wished for. Other than her character, the book is great. I really enjoyed it.
I picked this up because I hadn't seen the movie in years and wanted to read the original source. The characters were slightly different but overall I wasn't disappointed.
EXCELLENT. Read it, just do it. No really though, excellent book especially if you are a fan of Michael Crichton or any level of Sci-Fi / Adventure. Reads like a dream.

Isla Nublar, a small tropical Island just off the coast of Costa Rica is the lush backdrop against which the scene is set. Entrepreneur John Hammond has just realised the culmination of a dream: To have the long extinct  dinosaur walk the face of the earth once more. His motives are not science,  but profit- His. Hammond, through the research facility InGen, stumbled on  a surefire way to make a mountain full of money.  Through extracting dino  DNA from blood inside pre-historic mosquitoes that were trapped in tree  sap, and then fossilised into amber, it was possible to clone a living  dinosaur. Hammond loses no time in developing a full range of dinosaurs and  populating his island with them, in the quest to create the most astounding  theme park ever- Jurassic Park.  Of course having never encountered a  living dinosaur before, it is shown to the reader that the power of these  creatures has been drastically under-estimated. According to Ian Malcolm a  mathematical consultant brought in to access the feasibility of the park,  Chaos theory guarantees that such a venture is doomed to unpredictability  and will without question be headed for disaster. And so unfolds the tale.

If you are like me you will enjoy reading the action packed thriller "Jurassic Park".  It is just another one of Micheal Crichton's sensational novels that leave you hanging and asking for more.  The  bulk of this book is spent reading about a frantic dash to regain order on  an out of control island inhabited with some of the most deadly of  prehistoric creatures.  the characters in this book are left to compete  with such carnivorus predators as the Tyrannnosaurus Rex  , Dilophosaurus,  and the most deadly and feared of all the stealthy Velociraptor.  If that  isn't enough action and danger for you then through in a violent tropical  storm, an egocentric owner, a drunken security inspector, a scandelous  computer control operator, and a delirious mathmetician. That is what  thisbook has offer!  To top it all off Crichton throughs in two kids to  supply comic releif and his trade mark sceintific inquries.  Not to mention  some old fashion twists and turns.  In short "Jurassic Park"  has just about everything you could imagine.  If you choose this book to  read you are in for a treat.  Just as long as you stay away from the  predators.

Jurassic Park is Michael Crichton's masterpiece. He has made a book that make's the reader not want to stop reading it(which he has done more than once). The number one reason why I like it is the way he wrote it, not talking all the time, the closing gets even more face paced then the novel already is, and he provides you a lot detail with the fewest words possible, its a great read. It won't leave you in the dark when your finished with it like he did in Congo. I don't think he should of wrighten a sequel but I was satisfied with it after I read it so you will probably like it to.It's basically the same plot only with different action sequences. The thing he does best of course is his get down to the "blood and action" part, most authors spend a lot of time trying to make an underlying theme but he totally thoughs that out the window, he writes the book almost as if it actually happened. Its fast pace(doesn't slow the book down for anything except to explain some character backrounds) along with his dangerous dino's theme park theme(which sounds amazingly possible) make this book the best he will ever write.

I remember seeing the movie in theaters and being totally blown away by it.  Then just last year, I felt the need to read the book that started the movie craze.  The book was even more amazing.  The intricate details and pacing of the plot was masterful.  Crichton is the master at holding the readers attention throughout the book from the very beginning to the very last period on the last page.  This was not my first Crichton, but it definitely was one of my favorites.  The movie did justice to the events in the book, but the book upped it to the nth degree.  All of the scientific mumbo jumbo in both mediums were so intricately explained that I felt like I truly understood what they were talking about, even though I didn't have a clue.  The characters were completely lifelike and I couldn't help but visualize the movie adaptations of each as I was reading.  This book is one of my alltime favorites, and Crichton one of the best at what he does.  I love the implementation of science that propels many of his books, and I am always amazed at how much imagination went into each of his works.  He is missed and a great deal of joy was lost when he passed.
I've struggled staying interested in any books long enough to finish them for a couple of years now. I read this one in less than a week though. Loved every page!
Loved this book and the depth of knowledge shown throughout.  Thought that is was far superior to the movies and really found myself not able to put it down.

I have loved the Jurassic Park film for close to twenty years now and only just recently read the book. I was absolutely blown away by the book. As much as the film amazed me, and continues to do so, this book was incredible. There were some very stark differences between the book and film but I find them to be best suited in the context of their own rights. The story in the book is very heavily laden with science, to the point that its very believable (even to someone like myself who has extensive education in the sciences but is not a biologic expert). Also, the story in the book tends to be much darker and way more graphic than the film. I was also pleased at how easy of a read this book is. I tend to read novels that are usually in the 250-300 page range due to the simplicity of the story telling. This book is right around 400 and doesn't suffer from any drawn out story telling or redundancy. There is nothing worse than pleasure reading something that is densely packed with so much wordage that you can't make sense of what's going on. Luckily this book doe not suffer from that curse.
Well written.  Brings characters to life, both human and dinosaur!  Different than movie version, better storyline, more plausible, but just as exciting

Michael Crichton has concocted a story that seems more appropriate for the six-year-old-boy genre, but is definitely not a bedtime story.  In Jurassic Park, he takes a pose on the possibility of cloning dinosaurs from fossilized DNA, in the hopes that someday, a park will be built, and the proprietors will never go hungry again.  But things go afly (of course), and in the end, the island is firebombed to prevent these little scientific nightmares from getting off the island. The plot moves along nicely 95% of the time.  The other 5% Crichton uses to get way too tangled up in scientific fast-talking.  His science talk seems a bit contrived at times, and sometimes seems too coincidental, but in any case, Crichton has done his homework, and has presented us with a scenario that could happen...maybe.... Overall, I enjoyed this book.  It is a very engaging story that is hard to put down.  Although the movie is a gross disappointment of standards that only Hollywood could appreciate, the book itself is definitely worth a serious look.  I highly recommend it--for adults.

Jurassic Park is about a filthy rich man who hires people to collect amber with insects inside it.  Millions of years ago, the insects sucked the blood of dinosaurs in Jurassic times.  The scientists extract the blood  from the preserved insects, which has dinosaur DNA in it.  Then they  genetically engineer dinosaurs.  The rich man buys an island of the coast  of Costa Rica.  Then he makes a theme park that revolves around the  dinosaurs, on the island.  A few scientists and two kids come to observe  the dinosaurs on the island, so they were taken on a tour of the island.  But something went terribly wrong!  The power on the island was shut off,  including the electric fences.  The dinosaurs escape and run amok.  So the  people have to try to survive in the wild until the power comes back.  But  the dinosaurs have other ideas!  Jurassic Park  was a great thriller;  it was suspenseful and almost always exiting.  Some of the parts of the  book that had technical talk were kind of slow.  But the rest was  wonderful.  I highly recommend it: a real page-turner.
The product showed up. I liked the book itself, and I liked that the book wasn't thrashed, either. It was a simple, plain, unremarkable transaction.

This is one of those books that entertains you with great characters, an interesting premise, and manages to stimulate your brain and make you think  in the process. I devoured this book because it kept me interested the  whole way through... it was very hard to put down. Chrichton explains the  scientific aspects of his book very well and in the process, manages to  educate you, make you think, and perhaps give you some interest in new  fields (I had never heard of Chaos Theory until this book.) This is far  better than the cheap Spielberg movie that came after. I highly recommend  it to anyone who enjoys to be entertained without choking down brain-dead  material (a la most commercial fiction and bestsellers.) If you are not a  science fiction fan, do not worry; I am not either, but I loved to book  anyway. And I feel obligated to note that you should not judge this book  based on Chriton's other works (as often can be done); The Andromeda Strain  WAS awful, but this is not--I've also heard negative things about some of  his other early works.

In spite of my description of the characters in this novel as one-dimensional, I really enjoyed this book for the plot, science & action.  Frankly, I didn't care if I got to know the characters very well - they served their purpose, which was to promote the action.  I happen to fall into the philosophical category of "no, we should not EVER attempt to resurrect extinct species" (with the possible exception of a species recently extinct which was made that way solely through man's destructive habits), so I am sympathetic to the author's cautionary tale here.  Even if I weren't, the technical details add to - and manage not to convolute - the story line, and I had plenty of fun following the novel even though the movie (which I saw before reading this) was so different. I can enjoy them both separately for what they are.  I think this is one of the first really good futuristic-science-driven action stories (even if the science has been proven unsound) and it spawned a lot of imitators in the decades since its release.  Well worth the read.

I have read this book every year senice 1998. This is the best book I have read Jurassic Park, Dreamcatcher, and The lord of the rings are my top fav books of all time. This book is more on explaining stuff and a whole alot violent than the movie. Don't get me wrong The movie is my most fav movie of all time. But if I had the chance to remake the movie I would have the fisrt part on an hour and the rest of the movie just like in the book.EX t-rex to the end. The Velicorapters are scary. The book is gory beyond reason. The charictors are great. Hammond is a mean old fool. There is a lot of deaths in this book but the top honers go to Dr. Henry Wu and the near end. That's a death to remember. Robert Moldoon is a great person and so is Donnald Geinniro if they had there story line in the movie it would make the movie even better. The point is that Jurassic Park is the most fun you'll have on reading. It's got tons of action, gore, people, death, thought-provoking parts. If you like thicno thriller with a dash of horror then you will like this one.

I've seen almost complete 10's as I read through this review list.  I would have given it a 100 or better rating but 10 is pretty low for such a phenomenal book.  I've read it six times.  The first time I found Malcolm's droning to be boring and long, but I read it last week, and it seemed much less boring than the first five times.  Chaos theory doesn't exactly thrill me to say the most, but he doesn't talk about it much.  Muldoon is my favorite character, and I love the part when he blows the raptor in half with his bazooka.  I also like when he shoots the charging tyrannosaur with the tranq cylindar.  I can't believe how close the repair crews come to finding Grant and the kids after the attack on the main road, but it wouldn't have been as exciting if they had been found when Muldoon's crew was repairing the torn out section of fence. I would have liked the movie better if it was taken word-for-word from the book, but it was okay just the same.  I encourage everyone to read this techno-thriller.  It is definitely worth buying!

Any time an author can take something that automatically screams "no way," or "could never happen" and then makes it believable, they need to be applauded. Sure there were parts that seemed a bit of a stretch, but for the most part I felt "this could actually happen." I wish they would've arrived on the island and got to the dinosaurs sooner because the build-up did drag a bit, but it may not have had I not seen the film first and knew generally what was going to happen. The techno/biology stuff got a bit hard to care about at times but usually kept lamens enough to follow. I think the books is great and so many "scenes" found me on the edge of my seat. The characters are good but could've been more interesting or unforgettable(I prefer the characters in the sequel). I think the book could've ended a chapter early being that the absolute ending was one of the more unrealistic portions and follows a definite conclusion to the main conflict, leaving the last chapter or two unnecessary and, for me, unwanted.

I liked the book Jurassic Park, because it is very descriptive in it's detail.  It tells you when and where you are, basicly putting the whole scene around you.  It also describe's how a dinosaur eat's it's prey and  how much pain the prey is going though will being eaten.  What i don't  like about the book is the fact that there are so many character's in the  book.  There are too many name's and too many face's to remember for all  the character's.  It get's really confusing because you'll think that one  person is someone else, then when that someone else come's up you realize  that you were reading about a different person.  I would recomend this  book to anyone that can handle grusome detail of people being eaten by  dinosaur's.  I would probly recomend this book to anyone period because  every book deserves to be read.  I can't tell anyone what book they should  and shouldn't read.  You need to read it and decied for yourself. So read  Jurassic Park, and tell yourself wheather you like it or not.
Excellent book! A real page turner. Recommended for kids in high school or older! Middle school kids or younger, read at your own risk!!

"Jurassic Park" is sure to become a classic of literature. It is not only an awesome story that keeps any reader turning pages (something not many novels achieve), but it is an intelligent compression of subjects from  many grounds of science such as mathematics, paleontology, computers and genetics. It is particularly interesting when Crichton explains the whole park incident based on the chaos theory, or when the close to death mathematician reflects about our modern day world. The large number of characters on many different places of the island adds up a great suspense when their stories come together. The author managed to create a place so marvelous and visually beautiful that the reader at some point at the first quarter of the book would do anything to avoid the disaster which is obviously approaching. Definitely an intelligent and thrilling ride any reader of any age can experience (I was 12 when I did) and learn a lot about science in general.

The book is essentially about the reproduction of dinosaurs through genetic engineering with the aim of recreating and controlling them in an amusement park located on a remote island for the sole purpose of earning enormous profits. Of course, the masterminds behind this farfetched scheme failed to consider that the dinosaurs lived millions of years ago during another age in different climate conditions and that their behavior could not be controlled by man nor security measures installed at the park. Predictably, the predators are the main threat to the unlucky party of experts dispatched to the island. T-rexes, a dilophosaurus and dozens of fearsome velociraptors escape their confines through their savage, ferocious cunning as well as man's ignorance of the animals they attempt to reproduce. Michael Crichton's novel is heavy on technical details and medical theories that slow down the narrative in places, but the story remains a fine thriller.

This is without a doubt one of his best books to date. I first read this book when I was 10 and instently fell in love with it, and have since re-read the book at least 20 times. The book definetly keeps you on your toes and you never want to put it down(belive me I know, my 9th grade german teacher constintly had to tell me to put it away) the book would have gotten a 10 from me if not for the fact that alot of the Dinosaur information is a little off, for example. Velociraptors ar NOT 6 FEET TALL more like 3 the animal that possed such a threat resembles the Utah Raptor. and as for the fact that Dilophosaurs had 'Manes' and could 'Spit' poison has never been proven. and finaly the T-rex can only see movement? I doubt it! T-rex's had excelent vision! but other than a few 'Dino-misprints' the book excells and keeps you woundering 'is he going to die?. can she jump and make it into the pool?' well you'll just ahev to find out. Chad W. Sitar

i think Michael Chricton is an excellent novelist. Jurassic Park is an EXCELLENT book. The movie has nothing to do make with it.

I saw the movie and I loved it and then I read the book and found it so much more developed with realistic characters and a real plot. It is  definetly better than the movie and as usual Crichton keeps you at the edge  of your seat as you might say. The story starts with an old rich and  arrogant(not the very nice sweet old grandpa he plays in the movie)  buissnes man named Hammond gathers scientits and promises to payment to  take a shot at the impossible, to recreate an extinct species......To clone  dinosaurs, and put them in high secruity amuesment park Jurassic Park. Action packed and exciting. I read this before watching the movie. As entertaining as the movie is, the book was even more fun.
Best summer reading book for enjoyment. First read this when I was 12 and still try to do so yearly because I like it so much.

The hand gently,  slowly, pushed aside the ferns, felling a chill and thought, he's hunting  us!  The thrilling terrious come from Michael Crichton's Jurrasic Park.  The day has come when cloning dinasours dna has been revealed! Dinasours  still alive? No, but yes with the discribtive writing from Michael  Crichton.  The book is about two paleotologists that are at the new  world(Jurassic Park) to see if the park is good. Every thing is good, but  then the power goes out, the dinasours go free and dr. Satler and Dr. Grant  and two kids(tim and lex) are all lost in the park!  The book is so  good it was recommended by nine periodicals, including the USA Today and  the Plain dealier.
It was a requirement for my son at school. while we've seen the movie several times. It's a different experience reading it.

Who needs Spielberg!  Crichton's skill as a writer creates within our heads the whole gamut - the set, the atmosphere, the tension between characters.  Plus, its kinda exciting the way our brains goes "Whhaaa ..?" when we read about the nonsense that makes sense (ie the chaos theory) and of all things, a mosquito trapped in amber which has penetrated the hide of a T Rex (the audacity of the zinger!)  Crichton's scientific verbatim is highly compelling - because of him, I have decided not to search for the cure for cancer, but build Disneyland the second (actually it would be fifth but who's counting?)  THAT's how deep this book gets to you.  The problem with the movie is, its taken literally at face value - we lose all the social comentary, the philosophical wham and the insidiously technical way Crichton's ideas fall dead-center into you brain, and locks itself there forever

Genetically engineered dinosaurs placed in a budding theme park island, what can possibly go wrong in Michael Crichton's Jurassic Park? If you believe Ian Malcolm, life will find a way and screw up what illusions of control we think we have. What I love about Crichton's books is that the science makes the reader believe what is happening in the novel could really happen. The book makes you think. I love the nearly philosophical musings on Ian Malcolm. The dinosaurs are majestic and fearsome. The action and danger are real and immediate. Even though I have read this book several times throughout the years, it captures my imagination and takes my breath away. The book is quite different than the movie in many places, although both are spectacular. Jurassic Park by Michael Crichton has remained one of my all-time favorite books since I read it the first time in the mid-1990s.

Jurassic Park was loosely based on the facts of biology that theoretically let you clone an animal that is extinct.  At the beginning of the book is a small history lesson of biology and genetic engineering.  Later "Dr. Wu"(also in the movie) briefly explained how they got the DNA for the dinosaurs through extracting blood of mosquito type insects that were caught in amber and therefore fossilized, although this DNA was fragmented.  Dr. Wu put the fragmented DNA back together by adding thymine, adenosine, guanine, or cytosine back into the missing areas, as you would think this would create problems in the genetic code of the dinosaurs.  The book was riveting even during the explanations, especially when I have at least a basic understanding of the facts due to school this year.  Unfortunately the biological facts in the book seem to disappear after the first explanations.
What can I say? A wonderful novel of a strange prehistoric world in modern times.  Recommended and guaranteed to delight.

First of all, i thoroughly enjoyed this book. I have seen both the book and the movie and was glad to acknowledge how much better the book is than the movie. as with many good books, there are drawbacks, the characters were underdeveloped and one would have thought that with the trauma being experienced by the characters, he might have been able to include more character depth. also, the chaos theory sounded like it could have used a little more research, as it was not well explained and made it sound as if he did not know what he was talking about. the action and pace of the book was great, however, and if you don't mind a little goriness, i highly recommend this book. a note to other reviewers- read the book more carefully, yes, the t-rex did eat someone. he also presented plausible explanations as to why the velociraptors were the ones killing everybody.

Let me not say as others have already said that the book is better than the movie, though it is in some ways.  Movies and books are not the same medium.  Movies, lest we forget, are moving pictures; books are movements in the mind, and the mind can perform more trick photography, so to speak, than can any filmmaker.  I will, however, discuss the end of the book.  Raptors are amazing creatures, as Crichton has portrayed them.  They have an alarming intelligence.  Unlike the other animals on the island, they know that in order for them to thrive, they must make it to the mainland.  The survival of their species depends on it.  This personification of the raptors had me thinking about this book long after I had read it.  They're coming, they're coming, they're coming . . .

I would have givin it a four and a half star but i didn't know how. People don't want to read this book because they think they know what happens because they saw the movie. I pitty them because the book is filled with totally different conflicts, unlike the movie, it doesn't follow the same plot all the time. I realy enjoy this book so much because it's not just about dinosaurs getting loose on some tropical island, it has so much suspense because just like animals, dinosaurs can be unpredictable. Micheal Crichton really knew what he was talking about when he wrote this book because of the detail, its like your in the middle of it like a 3D movie at Universal! So i DARE you to read this book, you won't regret it, but just don't give up in tne beginning because its like a movie, it has an interview to the plot, then the action starts!

Okay, he could have done better. Sure, the dinos might have had poison. Did the velociraptors really have to eat their dead? They hunt in a pack. They don't eat members of the pack when they  are still alive and wounded,  but they eat them when the raptor is breathing its last breath.  About  the characters. They seem a bit shallow, and a few even seem crazy. The  chaos was a bit outrageous, but oh-so predictable. (Malcolm imitation.)See  the underlying patterns!The park is  going to fail, blah blah, fall into a  coma, wake up for morphine, swear, talk about paradigms, blah  blah, here  come velociraptors, gasp, oh hi Grant, it's going to fail..... If you  really want a good book where you can sit patiently and wait for the  profanity, gore and stupid,going-against-common- sense-and-knowledge pages  to end, this is a good book.
the book came in really good shape, my son wanted this book very much. it is hard to find , so glad you were there.

This novel is remarkable in the way it understands the mass market and can  dumb-down literature to the level of a Steven Spielberg movie, in advance  of Spielberg taking over and doing just that.  The cavalier way Spielberg  changed and juked the story around to make it into not one but two movies  shows these two were made for each other :) Anybody can read this novel and  not strain their brain, or upgrade their reading skills beyond about 8th  grade.  A profound masterwork of an author who gives people what they want  rather than what he wants them to have, and my hat's off to him for showing  a budding author the Way :) How about a sequel giving Spielberg an excuse  for re-creating the Ice Age and its woolly mammoths and fantastic ice  world? :)  Another re-creating pre-human man-apes :)  Another re-creating  ...
Classic. Fans of the movie are sure to find this fascinating. Take a read and see the real story of Jurassic park.
Couldn't wait to turn the next page! So much better than the movie. A good read even if you're not into dinosaurs!

I read this book when I was in 6th grade.  Having the mind of a 6th grader, it scared the bujeebas outta me.  I was (kinda still am) an amateur dinosaur expert, and the book was as realistic as anything I'd ever and have ever read.  I've read the book about 4 times, and although the movie was great, it was not nearly as good as the book.  Although dinosaur theory changes with the weather, it still states some facts that are viable and consistent with modern theory (although I never truly understood why ALL the dinosaurs with frog DNA reproduced, wouldn't you think some might not have "done the deed"?)  Oh, if you want to be disappointed, read the sequal.  It was not worthy of its predecessor, although it was ok otherwise.  I think Crichton was trying to please the movie-masses and not the literary-masses.

Jurassic Park is the first Michael Crichton book I read, and it converted me to a big fan of his! I usually don't enjoy novels set in modern time, preferring historical fiction. But who can resist the thrills of Jurassic Park and the many exciting encounters with dinosaurs? If you love the movie, you'll enjoy the book even more! Believe it or not, Crichton's book is packed with even more edge-of-your-seat action and scary moments than the blockbuster movie. Although it's been proven that Crichton's "science" behind recreating dinosaurs has lots of loopholes, at best, you'll believe it's all possible once you read this book. The only I drawbacks I can find with "Jurassic Park" are that parts of it are intensely violent and it is filled with vulgar language. So it is not a suitable book for younger readers.

If you haven't read this book I really reccomend it. It is the best book ever written in my opinion. Many books lose you half way through, or don't have enough detail to get your mind jump started. This book doesn't waste a single word. If you have read it and have one bad thing to say about you probably really didn't understand it or are some sort of anti-techno-thriller. It is clearly Michael Crichton's best book, and he is the best author. Why is there so much Harry Potter hype when this book has been sitting on shelves since 1990? Michael Crichton has more skill than J.K Rowling could even hope to have. This is the book that should always be recognized as a true masterpiece. And also- I reccomend other Crichton novels. This totally will make Harry Potter look boring and stupid after you read it.

I bought Jurassic Park because I loved Crichton's Timeline so much. Jurassic Park was very well written, and you can tell that a lot of research went into making this book.Mass amounts of description is  used,  which is why I don't reccomend this book for young adults.Although there is  some gore and some phrases that make chills run along your back, the book  is still decent which is one of the reason I liked it so much.I am glad Mr.  Crichton kept it clean enough for people to read. I love all the science  that is in the book, as well as being able to think that it could really  happen in the near future.I also enjoyed the life that was put into the  characters. Ian Malcom was one of my favorites. The ending was especially  creative and well planned. I look forward to reading The Lost World.

Michael Chrichton is a brilliant writer with a keen imagination. His best  work to date--in my opinion--is "Jurassic Park." Like H.G. Wells  before him, Chrichton makes his readers believe that what he's writing  about could actually happen. As a dinosaur lover, I found this book to be  very entertaining (and much better than the movie). The only bad thing is  that the premise (and Ian Malcom's chaos theory) is based on evolution.  Contrary to what the media says, scientists are abandoning this so-called  theory in droves. If one were to seriously examine the evidence against  evolution--that is, macroevolution--(the fossil record, structural  homology, molecular biology), he would be forced to admit that evolution is  just another feeble attempt to deny the existance of a Creator.

I was in the sixth grade when I saw Jurassic Park on the big screen. I immediately picked up the book. Even though I was in sixth grade I understood it immensly and enjoyed thoroughly. I went on to read the book 3 more times, watch the movie twenty times, listen to the Audio Book twice, and read other greatly written books by Mr. Crichton. I have almost read all of them. Jurassic Park is a glorious read and is one of the most thrilling books there is. It is very descriptive and it has an addictive story line. If you've seen the movie don't pass up the book because it is so much better. The movie couldn't have a budget large enough to depict the whole book, but your mind needs no help from money to put the story into motion! A definite read!! (Also, don't get me wrong the movie is awesome!

Enjoyable as it was 20 years ago.  Lots of tension, and hard to put down. This is the 'best of' for Crichton.
This tape of the story is all that is available. I assume it is unabridged. It functioned well  as described.

"Jurassic Park" is a great novel that I think ranks as one of Crichton's best.  It has the feel of a classic, one of those ideas where you say, "Why didn't I think of that?"  One might make the argument that the (human) characters take a back seat to the dinosaurs, but I don't believe this is the case- I found the characters to be well developed and interesting.  Crichton also seems to do the dinosaurs justice, as he seems to have done his homework on this subject, though I'm guessing some in the scientific community might say that he's taken a few liberties in speculating about some of the dinosaurs' characteristics.  But that's artistic license.  Overall, a highly entertaining and imaginative novel.  Avery Z. Conner, author of "Fevers of the Mind".

Many people have seen the amazing movie, along with the ever so disappointing sequal, however, I would be willing to bet that now nearly as many have read the marvelous book.  First of all, if you liked the movie, the book will become an instant classic to you, and even if you didn't like the movie, you would still enojoy the book.  I never enjoyed reading very much, but after reading this book, it changed my view on books.  I went out and picked up the sequal (which was also much better than the movie), and several other Crichton books.  Basically, Chrichton changed the way I view books.  His books were the keys that opened the doors to my brain, and my imagination.  This is a great book by a great author, and I advise anyone who has not yet read it to go out and pick up a copy.
Jurassic Park is one of my favorite books. It never gets old; I've read it at least 20 times over the years.

Welcome to 'Jurassic Park', where reconstructed dinosaurs roam free, due to a radical breakthrough in DNA biological engineering.  A modern day Disney Park where the rides have considerably more bite, and terror.  Michael criton has created a sophisticated book, where he uses dinosaurs as  a metaphor for the advent of modern technology.  Unlike the movie which is  purely focuses on special effects and eerie sound effects (which I still  thoroughly enjoyed), this book has a fantasy, scientific and environmental  elements.  All of which I think Criton tries to portray through the  different characters in the book. ie. The scientist, the Billionaire who  never thinks of consequence, etc.  If you enjoyed Contact by Carl Sagan,  then I would definitely recommend this book.
Great book, I highly recommend it to anyone who is a fan of Jurassic Park or anything with dinosaurs in it

Sadly, I saw the movie first and had no idea what I was missing by not reading the book. I was 13 when I saw the movie and I was literally shaking in my seat. It was like a rollercoaster. A few years later someone had mentioned that I should read the book because it was better. I didn't believe them. I later took a vacation to Myrtle Beach and needed something to read on the ride down. I couldn't put the book down. This will be my third copy, as I always seem to lose the book. To this day, I have never found any dinosaur books that even come close. Does anyone know of anything that is similar to Jurassic Park? I've read "The Genesis Protocol" and "The Relic". Both are decent, but didn't give me that same feeling of excitement that Jurassic Park gives me.

Jurassic Park the movie does a grave injustice to the book.  Riviting and scary ..., it doesn't go overboard with the dinosaurs and the techonolgy.  Dr. Alan Grant and Elle Sattler are asked to take a tour of a magnificent new park. The evasive owner of the biotechnology company In-Gen and owner of the park John Hammond is there as well to supervice the epedition.  The park is located on an island 80 miles west of Costa Rica. Isla Nublar is the perfect setting for suck a book.  Grant and Sattler are joined by chaos therosist Ian Malcolm (my favorite character) and lawyer Donald Gennaro.  This book will take you on a roller coaster ride that doesn't have too many thrills and spills. The end of the book is very beautiful, but very gritty at the same time.

A wonderful story, with good characters.  When you read any of his other books, like Sphere or Rising Sun, you realise how light haearted and fun Crichton has made this book.  It appears as though he was just having some  fun with some briliant ideas when he wrote this.  Although the movie is one  of my all time favorite corn-ball movies, up there with Starship Troopers,  the book is nothing short of amazing.  The detail with which he writes this  story make you dread the last page, because the story can only get better.  The Lost World picks up where it left off, but would have also been able to  be a stand alone text, but JP clears up any confusion that a single Lost  World would have made.  Can't wait for the rest of the trilogy of  Dino-thrillers.

I repeat: anyone who gave this book less than a perfect 10 is obviously a crazy, half-witted moron with no sence of imagination, creativity, or humor.  Jurassic Park is by far the ABSOLUTE BEST book that I have ever read!!  It's fast-paced, exciting, and (believe it or not) much better than the movie!!!  I loved every minute of it!!  Some may say that it's not 'correct' in it's ideas about dinosaurs and cloning, but truthfully enough the best books are the kind that often leave behind the real and plausible world as we know it and give us something to dream about.  Jurassic Park is a great techno-thriller that incorporates genetics, death and destruction, and a lesson about tampering with nature into one novel.  READ IT!  DEFINITELY READ IT!!

Jurassic Park, by Michael Crichton, is a highly technical, science thriller.  Written two years before the subsequent movie was released, the main characters profession-and ultimately what gets the story going- on the works of paleontologist Jack Horner.  Being far more technical than the movie, the novel uses a wide range of scientific information to support the very ficticious plot.  Diagrams help to give the sense that your admiring a computer rather than a computer screen.  Michael Crichton uses a variety of complex words to add to it's intense feel.  The main point is clear, and concise from the beginning of the book. While some remark that why would you read a book there is already a movie of, I believe that the book is well worth reading.

Well done Crichton! I yelled at this book laughed at and dreaded other parts. I feel like this book should get more recognition.I found that the writer used suspense well among other good points. The science he used to explain certain things seemed solid for the sake of this book. I did not find all the characters believable though ..cough ...'Grant '. Am I really supposed to believe that you are not afraid to go in a raptor nest? yea right. Anyway the character Hammond was someone I really wanted to like .He seemed so optimistic and hopeful about the park. He was delusional though! Still the characters were all engaging and the deaths were truly terrifying. I will definitely recommend this to friends and reread it in the future.

I love this book. Mostly, I like this book because it's exciting, it has good character plots, and is also funny in some parts. The characters are Lex, Tim, Dr. Alan Grant, Dr. Ian Malcom, and Dr. Ellie Sattler, and many more.  The book is about a group of people getting stuck on an island full of dinosaurs during a storm.  The book is really exciting, and the best parts, I think, are when the Velociraptors are around.  If I was forced to say 2 bad things about the book, it would be: Goryness and cuss words. Lay off the cuss words, ok[Michael]!? The autors name is Michael Crichton, and he has written many of my most favorite books, such as Timeline and Sphere.  Take a break, J.K. Rowling!  This guy will always be tops on my list!

This book is an excellent read, but don't be fooled by all of the comments and praise for this book: it is NOT Crichton's best ever. That distinction belongs to Sphere, or maybe even Disclosure. It is very good, even addictive, and it is entertaining, but it is simply overrated. Crichton brings us a story about an island devoted to dinosaurs run by an eccentric old man with deep pockets. Inevitably, something goes horribly wrong, and people start dropping like flies as the remaining ones struggle to remain alive. It is a lot different than the movie, and it is undeniably better, even though I liked the movie a lot. It certainly ends differently. All in all this is a standout book, but a bit overrated, and not Crichton's best.

Excellent detail and descriptiveness. It is perfect for anyone who enjoys complexities and suspense, but can't stand boring parts. I remember when I first started reading it, I didn't think would like it too much. I read two more pages and after that, read 'till midnight, I swear. One of the things that keeps the book going is the continuous happening of events. Things never stopped popping up after that first part. Another thing was the accuracy on the dinosaurs. He describes every last detail right on the dot to last vertabrae on a tyrannosaur's tail, and I'm serious about that, 37 vertabrae, he says it. I'd give this book a 1,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000-star rating if I could, but they only let me put in five.

The movie did the book no justice. This story captured the reader's mind and let thier imagination recreate the awesome and powerful creatures that have long been extinct.  There are so many differences between the movie and book it would be almost impossible for me to name them all. I only gave this book four stars because some parts, like the scientific things and the DNA, were difficult to understand. But all that aside, if you liked the movie, try reading the book. Crichton has created a real masterpiece. if you have a weak stomach and don't think you can handle a man holding his own intestines, think twice, but other than that, read on!! (there are different characters in the book, so the book is a lot better.)

Even if you're like me and have already seen the movie, please still go ahead and read this book!!  It's not very often that I find a movie better than the book but in this case, I'd have to give the movie and the book 5 stars but on the other hand, the book has far more detail and although you know what is about to happen if you have seen the movie, it's still very suspenseful and has you on the edge of your seat until you turn the last page.  Michael Crichton is a brilliant writer who has no problem writing about entirely different subjects.  I mean, what do dinosaurs and female sexual harrassers have to do with each other?  Either way, this is a must read book for your collection and I fully recommend it.

This is the center piece of Crichtons' work. Crichton has the skill to take a far away idea  and make it real. How could dinosaurs exist today? Most dino movies or books are them  selvs fantasy and lacking a reason for why dinosaurs are alive in modern times.  Suppose that the technology advanced so that dinosaurs would not need to be transported  through time or be robots, but to be recreated, alive in their full glory. How would one  fund such an operation? What would be needed? Who be the ones to do it? How would it  be done? How could you manage such an operation? etc.  Crichton brings all the questions together, mixes it with fear and fact, and produces a very  entertaining tail of greed and power.

This is a very good book, way better than the movie could ever hope to be, but the mass market paperback version is complete garbage. The spelling and grammar mistakes in the book are unimaginable - periods in the middle of sentences, all kinds of extra commas that didn't appear in the original version, dozens of instances of "th" being replaced by "m" (for instance, "mat" instead of "that" and "mere" instead of "there"). The book is incredibly well written but either the publisher or the printer royally f***ed up their job. Buy it at Barnes & Noble and get a copy where you don't constantly have to stop and figure out WTF is supposed to be written there.

This was an excellent book! It had a great plot, and lots of gore [I love that]! However, some things about 1 of the dinosaurs was incorrect. The Dilouphasaurs [or however you spell it!] in real life, didn't have the frill, and were a LOT bigger!! I heard that they were auctually around 7-9 feet tall! Other than that, I thought that everthing was pretty much correct. It was an exciting book, and one I wuld recommend for anyone who loves gore [NOT the incredibly boring vice-president!] and excitment! ALSO!!! With you people who are critisizing the book and giving it low ratings because he missed on a few facts, STOP!!! It's okay to make a mistake!! Besides! This is a FICTION book, is it not? ;
Great book explained a lot. I saw the movie first a long time ago. They did a great job on both

Jurassic Park is without a doubt, the best book I have ever read! The story is of course ficticious: a team of scientists create and clone dinosaurs; but as I read it, it seemed to me that a scientist could  actually clone dinosaurs based on reading this book!  Author Michael  Crichton knows how to write a compilcated story and make it enjoyable to  read. The book is stuffed with suspense and action packed adventure.  Suprisingly, I also learned a little bit about dinosaurs. This is a  phenomonal book and if you don't believe ME, go by Steven Spielberg, one of  the greatest directors of all time who decided that Jurassic Park was so  good, he made a movie out of it. Top reading!

I have this book for about a year now and I have read it at least 20 times. I just simply love it. It is the best book by MC, I guarantee you. Don't miss the chance to read it if you haven't done so already. Also don't read beyond this point if you haven't read it before. Some people do find MC's style a little gruesome, especially when he writes about coils of intestines, etc. But still, its great. The action just takes you into the characters' world and you feel as if you're 'in the book'. When the action stops, it is replaced by interesting facts. I never skipped them while I read it. This was the second book I read written by MC and since then I've read almost all of them.

I liked the movie.  Until I read the book.  The story, in its real version, is compelling and thoughtful.  Those who choose not to read a book after having seen the movie it has spawned, consider making an exception.  Jurassic Park, the movie, was watered-down and flat-out changed to make it an acceptable family film.  The book is far more brutal and honest.  Get past Malcomb's character and you've got a great read.  Malcomb was the one facet of the movie that improves on the book - the paper version of the mathematician is a one-dimensional, whining character that the author uses as a direct mouthpiece.  Transparent and bordering on noxious.  Otherwise thoroughly enjoyable.

The velociraptors are the stars of this book, just as they were in the movie. Time and again they menace the human heroes, seeming all the more threatening because they are human-sized and can get inside buildings. As always, Crichton's human characters are a little on the uninteresting side, but that doesn't stop the plot from screaming along. The only recent dino novel I would give a higher rating is Hopp's new, "Dinosaur Wars." There, the human-sized, feathered megaraptors are even scarier than velociraptor, if that's possible, and the lead characters (a young man and woman) are a bit more engaging than Ian Malcolm. Still, Jurassic Park deserves high marks.

Jurassic Park is a grippping suspense thriller where the unpredictable is natural. The book is much better than the movie, and shows alot more detail in the dinosaurs themselves. Alan Grant and his assistant Ellie Sattler are invited by a lunatic millionare to visit his "Theme Park" where he has bred living diosaurs. Of course, something bad happens and the dinosaurs run amok in the park, killing an extreme amount of people. Over all, Jurassic Park is a wonderful book which can be easily visalised as you read. Of course, there are elements that tha were left out from the movie (The giant "birdcage"), and the movie spawned 2 horrible sequels.

Jurassic Park is a grippping suspense thriller where the unpredictable is natural. The book is much better than the movie, and shows alot more detail in the dinosaurs themselves. Alan Grant and his assistant Ellie Sattler are invited by a lunatic millionare to visit his "Theme Park" where he has bred living diosaurs. Of course, something bad happens and the dinosaurs run amok in the park, killing an extreme amount of people. Over all, Jurassic Park is a wonderful book which can be easily visalised as you read. Of course, there are elements that tha were left out from the movie (The giant "birdcage"), and the movie spawned 2 horrible sequels.
An excellent book. Crichton does an excellent job writing. Can't wait to read the sequal.

...My favorite book I have read was Jurassic Park.  The story was suspenseful and very easy to follow.  I thought that the story was hard to believe, but the characters are extremely believable. The area that the story takes place is on an island by Costa Rica.  The plot twists and turns in so many directions that it keeps the story exciting and kept me interested in reading the book.  I could not put the book down.  It was so good I read it in three days.  Michael Crichton is the author of the book.  He goes into detail in all his books to entertain people.  The book is a New York Times best-selling book, and the author is a best-selling author.
I had worn out my old copy, so I just needed a new one. I already knew that I loved it!

I saw the movie first and I loved it and then I saw the novel and so I bought it and I wasn't the least bit disapointed. The book hooked me and took me on a wild ride! I thought that it was way better than the movie  because I got a lot more out of the book, the book is educational and  exciting at the same time. Yes, the characters aren't very developed but  they're developed enough for me! Some of the characters are a little bland,  i.e Arnold, but some of the characters are great, i.e Malcolm and Muldoon.  The writing style really good and Crichton surely did a lot of research for  this book! This is a must-read for everyone!

This was my first Crichton book. I have to say it may very well be my favorite book ever. I was so impressed the way this book was written, as well as his other books. The movie came first for me, and even thoush it was great, the book was still better. The action was excellent, not to mention how descriptive it was. If anyone is looking for a thriller, this is the book to read. Although half of the book is setting up the plot and focusing on technical crap, but once the excitement starts it never stops. I have read the book three times, and still love it as much as the first time I read it. Read this book, you wont regret it.

Michael Crichton made many great books but this book topped off everything he every written in his life! The book tells us of the dangers of genetic technology and cloning dinosaurs is just asking for a bite. The plot: Alan Grant and Ellie Sattler recieve a call from their supplier, John Hammond, about a top-secert "park" he is working on and invites them to come. But something horrible happens on the island. This is the book that was turned into the incredible Jurassic Park triolgy. My grade:A+. A classic novel by the genius author Michael Crichton. Not to be missed by anyone near interested in good, ingaging stories.

Great book.  The book is very different from the movie.  Some main characters  die in the book and not in the movie and the ending is totally different from the first movie.  There is a lot more detail given in the book about Chaos Theory, the dinosaurs and how they are made and the computer system , almost too much detail.  I have seen all three movies and while it would have been complicated to make the first movie exactly like the book it would have been a great movie.  The author really did a lot of research before writing this book and it really shows.  I look forward to reading the rest of this series.

If you enjoyed the hit movie, then you will love the book.  Scientists have found a way to recreated dinosaurs and they make an amusement park containing the beasts!  The owner of the park invites guests down to the  island, and everything goes as planned--until the main compute programmer  turns off the island's power!  Crichton's insight into theories are great,  and the action is intense!  This book is impossible to put down; it also  blows the movie clear out of the water.  I have the original paperback, but  I am planning on getting a hardcover version.  Dinosaur fan or not, this  book is for you.

Jurassic Park is one of the most exciting books I have ever read.  It is the book that re invigorated my love of reading.  I read it a few years before the movie so I didn't know what to expect.  Upon reading it I was fascinated with his opening on  bio-genetics and then awestruck with the way the story unfolded.  As a kid  who loved dinosaurs, it was fantastic to see them in this setting.  I  thought about how neat it would be if this world really did exist and I  imagined myself in there with the characters.  I thank Crichton for all his  fantastic books!

I have read Jurassic Park, and I am very much impressed.  The writer has done a teriffic job of research, and he really stretched his imagination. I found this to be a wonderful book.  It is a little less frustrating to read  about the action as  it develops then be captivated by the horrors of the  movie.  I saw the movie first, and I just read the book.  Right after, I  read the book the Lost World was shown on television.  The Lost World made  a lot more sense after I had read Jurassic Park.  I think that we should  give thumbs up to this book.  I see this book as a remarkable literay  achievement.

Sometimes novels with movie adaptations go unread, but "Jurassic Park" is an exception for me. This was a novel that I simply could not put down from the moment I opened the cover page. Michael Crichton paints a vivid picture that not even the movie, which happens to be my favorite film, can compete with. The thrilling nature of the plot and an appropriate balance between reality and fiction made this novel so enjoyable. Crichton's story succeeded in keeping me engulfed throughout the entire book. I would recommend it to anyone who has seen the movie or to any lover of science fiction novels.

It was very interesting to read.  For me, it was two night's worth of reading.  the characters were well designed and left room for interpretation.  I found that had a very good ending.  It was enjoying to  read exactly why the dinosaurs were the way that they were and how they  would react if they were ever brought into this world.  It was interesting  to read about the raptors and their way of hunting.  The detail within the  novel shows that Crichton put forth a lot of effort to bring about a good  novel.  His plot is good.  Everything that was good in this novel was  destroyed by the movie.

I'm almost eleven, and this is my first real novel and probably the best book I've ever read.  It is amazing to me how Michael Crichton describes every little detail possible.  He fascinates me with all of the high-tech  DNA strand ideas and especially the graphs and charts.  This is the first  time ever that I've forgotten about TV, and read instead.  I recommend this  book to anyone in middle school or above.  This brought me out of my OLD  favorites, the Oz series (but still good books), and into a new dimension.

Jurassic Park is a realistic look at a very unrealistic possibility - the re-creation of dinosaurs using modern day technology.  Chrichton is a master of suspense - this book is a definate page turner.  The plot is both adventurous and exciting - an extremely rich business owner buys an island and hires scientists to create dinosaurs using amber extracted from rocks.  This amber contains dinosaur dna trapped in mosquitos.  The plan is to create an amusement park featuring these new dinosaurs.  Of course, something disastrous occurs.  I highly recommend this book for mature teens and adults.

I read this book in 8th grade and I thought it was pretty good. It's the kind of book that makes you want to keep reading and reading untill bedtime. The book gives you so much background info and so much more action, and gruesome killings then in the movie which most people love as much as me. I loved the movie and the book, I feel that there both on the same line of rating. So don't feel that if you've seen the movie, reading the book would be pointless, the book has a different ending and many more people die. The book is worth the money, so if you don't already have it, pick it up.

By now, most people have seen the movie adaption of Jurassic Park. I think it's safe to say it was well liked and memorable. The original novel is so much more. With more background, more authentic (if not always easily understood) science and lots of detailed description that paints a picture more fantastic than the film's special effects could ever hope to reproduce, Jurassic Park is a book not to be missed. Action, adventure, dinosaurs, DNA, cloning, ethical/moral dilemmas and so much more, Michael Crichton's Jurassic Park cannot be completely appreciated without reading this book.

After seeing the movie numerous times I didn't really want to read the book because I thought that it would be almost exactly like the movie. How wrong I was. The book and the movie are similar but different in enough ways to make reading the book a different experience. If you have seen the movie and liked it read the book and you'll wish it had become the movie. I thought it was strange that Jurassic Park 3 used a variation of the pteridactyl part from the original Jurassic Park book. I guess they realized they shouldn't have left it out in the first movie after all. Great book!

Jurassic Park was a very fun, exciting book written by Michael Crichton.  I really enjoyed the action in the book; however, some of it was gruesome and disgusting.  Many people died, but who cares anyway.  In the book Richard Hammond clones dinosaurs with ancient blood from bugs trapped in amber.  He used the DNA to clone dinosaurs to make lots and lots of MONEY!!!  But sometimes the dinosaurs escaped and reeked havoc on the park.  Eventually the dinosaurs can reproduce making loads and LOADS of vicious velociraptors.  How will they control the dinos?  Read the book to find out.

Beleive me, this is the best book I have ever read!!! If you saw the movie and you thought it was anywhere between good and the best film ever made, read this book. It is all because of Mr. Crichton's style and way of  writing things. He is an amazing person. He would do tons of research and  studying just for one book. It realy shows in Jurassic Park and his later  book, The Lost World. (I also did a review for that book). So, in short, it  doesn't matter if you read the mass made paperback, the library-bound  hardcover or even listen to it on tape or CD, you will love it!

I loved this book! This is coming from a 12 year old who has read it 4 times! I didn't get a lot of the science stuff but oh well. It had things that weren't mentioned in the movie, like the Hadrosaurs and the  Pterodactles. The river ride was radacle! It was cool how they fell down  the waterfall into the reach of a Tyranosaur! Oops! For those who haven't  read it, I suggest this be your next choice of reading material! Many  things are different, changed, or not in the movie. The start of the Lost  World movie is the begining of JP the book. Sooooo...... READ THIS BOOK!

This is one of the best books I ever read. My first taste of it was about two months after the movie came out. While the movie is quite an achievement, the book is far better. The actions scenes are nonstop and the science in the book is astonishing. The nature of each character is much deeping than the movie, expecially Ian Malcolm. If you thought the T-Rex scene was great in the movie, there are far greater ones in the book, including a chase in the jungle river. Crichton's no-nonsense style grabs you in the first page and never let you go. A must read for sci-fi fans.

I read this book a couple years ago and recently re-read it. I think that this is one of the best pieces of dinosaur fiction out there. Even though the book can get really boring (with all the science and biotechnology and chaos theories), it has many exciting action scenes. Also, this book is more violent than the movie (excellent flick), with more blood and gore. Also, there are some major differences between the movie and the book. However, both are very good and are worthy of your time.

A book about Dinosaurs terrorizing a group of people who on a secluded island makes for a great adventure book.  This book is the investigation of an island that soon will be opened to the public.  And what the characters find is an island of terror where the Dinosaurs are let loose and thereafter terrorize the human characters, therefore, asking the question "Does man really control nature?".  This book is a great read if you are looking for a fast paced action adventure that also going into the details of the area and characters.  One of Crichton's best books.

When I first read the book, I didn't realize how much Crichton really emphasized his support for the chaos theory and the whole nonlinear dynamics. The manner in which he portrays this theory is almost convincing. After I read the book a second time, I was asking myself the question of whether this strange but oddly captivating theory was true or not. A masterpiece. If only all sci-fi/thriller novels could be as intriguing as this book is. It will leave you on the edge of your seat up till the very end. I would suggest this book to anyone seeking a thrill ride.

I am a huge fan of the JP series.  I have watched the movies countless times. I went in reverse order by reading the book afterwards.  No matter. The book was fantastic and, having already seen the movies, it was easier to imagine the scenery and the characters. The end left questions......  Not necessarily in a bad way though. It just now makes me want to get the Lost World, even though I didn't think the movie was as good as it could have been. Everyone knows about this book by now. Even if you've seen the movie, this is definately still worth the read!

This book was my first Chrichton novel I have read.  It was great.  Although at times it was a greusome or vulgar it was still a great book!  It makes you think what if...  My favorite part about the whole book is that it isn't one of those extrealmy predictibe you know it will turn out all good at the end books.  THis book left you hanging at the end of each chapter!  I even stayed up till 12:30 one night just reading it!  I saw the movie before I read the book.  The Movie left so much out.  If you thouhgt the movie was good then you will LOVE the book!

This book is a fun-filled, action-packed novel.  I would say it would have  to be one of the best of Crichton's novels.  The way he descibes everything  is just simply amazing.  It makes me feel like I am right there seeing  everything and experiencing everything.  This book is one you can't put  down.  One thing that he does in his books is change what is being led to  so the main part of the story is not discovered until the end of the book.  If you've seen the movie before reading the book, you will be amazed at  what was actually supposed to happen.

I think Jurassic Park should was a great book, thats why i gave it four stars. I like for bookis to go right into the action and Jurassic Park took about two or three pages and thats what i liked about it. i also like the fact that they used the same names like in the movie so the readers woulnt get confused. Jurassic Park is a book about a man who decides to create an island and make dinosaurs, a few experts come to the island and everything goes wrong. The dinosaurs start to attack the people and the people have to try and get away in one piece.

This book is awesome! Of all of the sci-fi thrillers I have read, Jurassic Park is #1. This book is hard to put down and has non-stop action. A must read and must buy! The plot of this book is when a rich man, John Hammond, buys a secluded island off Costa Rica. He hires the best of the best scientists to create bioengineered dinosaurs from fossiled amber. He invites 2 paleontoligists (Alan Grant & Ellie Sattler) , a lawyer (Donald Genarro), and a mathematician (Ian Malcolm) to tour the island. Eventually it turns to disaster . . . A MUST READ!!!

After getting through the first few chapters of the book I was unable to put it down.
